notesStmt.note: Later enlarged editions (both in English and Latin) were published under title: Myographia nova.
The description of the muscles is based on William Molins' Myskotomia, and the plates on Guilio Casserio's Tabula anatomicae.
Reproduction of original in Library of Congress.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A Compleat Treatie OF THE MUSCLES, As they appear in Humane Body, And arie in DISSECTION; With Divere Anatomical Obervations Not yet Dicover'd.
Illutrated by near Fourty COPPER-PLATES, Accurately Delineated and Engraven.
By John Browne, Sworn Chirurgeon in Ordinary to His Majety.
Non Nobis Nati.
In the SAVOY. Printed by Tho. Newcombe for the Author. 1681.

TO HIS Mot Sacred Majety CHARLES II. By the Grace and Providence of God KING OF Great Brittain, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c. THESE Anatomical Exercitations OF MUSCULAR DISSECTION, Are mot Humbly Dedicated,
div.byline: by Your Majeties Mot Loyal Subject, And mot Obedient Servant, John Browne.

div.head: Charles R.
div.p:
CHARLES By the Grace of God, King of England, Scotland, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c. To all Our loving Subjects of what Degree, Condition, or Quality oever within Our Kingdom and Dominions, Greeting: Whereas it hath been manifeted unto s, that Our Truty and Welbeloved John Browne Eq one of Our Chirurgeons in Ordinary, hath not only with great Art, but at the Expence of much Time and Charge, delineated, decribed, and accurately Engraved in Copper-plates an Anatomical Treatie of Mucular Diection; which performance of his is to Our great liking and atisfaction, o that We may expres Our Approbation thereof, and give him all due and ample encouragement for the future; We do hereby ignifie Our Royal Pleaure, granting unto the aid John Browne the ole Priviledge of Printing the aforeaid Treatie with its Copper Figures; and trictly Charging, prohibiting and forbidding all Our Subjects to Copy or Counterfeit any the Sculptures or Decription aforeaid, either in great or mall, or to Import, Buy, Vend, tter, or Ditribute any Copies or Exemplars of the ame Reprinted beyond the Seas within the term of Fifteen Years next enuing the Date of this Our Licene, and Prohibition, without the Conent and Approbation of the aid John Browne, his Heirs, Executors and Aigns, as they and every of them o offending will anwer
the Wardens and Company of Stationers of Our City of London, the Farmers, Commiioners, and Officers of Our Cutoms, as all other Our Officers and Miniters whom it may concern, are to take particular notice that due Obedience be given to this Our Royal Command.

closer.dateline: Given at Our Court at Whitehall this 22th Day of Nov. in the Three and thirtieth Year of, &c.
closer.signed: By His Majeties Command, L. Jenkins.

div.head: To His Grace CHRISTOPHER Duke of Albemarle, Earl of Torington, Baron Monck of Potheridge, Beauchamp, and Teyes, Knight of the Mot Noble Order of the Garter, One of the Gentlemen of His Majeties Bed-Chamber, One of His Majeties mot Honourable Privy-Council, Lord Lieutenant of the Counties of Devon and Eex, And Captain of His Majeties Guards of Hore.
div.p:
HIS Majety having been Graciouly pleaed not only to take a view of, but to allow the Publication of this Treatie of Mucular Diection; Now after Him it waits at Your Graces Feet, imploring Your Pardon for its Preumption: But Your Generous Spirit always encouraging the Indutrious Man, breathes Life into my ndertaking, by which Your Grace does declare to the World Your valuable Goodnes, as well as Your ubtantial Honour: You never exerciing Your elf in little Deigns, but in the Publick Service of Your King and
Countrey; Thee being the main Columnes of Your Great Lutre, all which when Greatnes hall be hrivel'd into nothing, or at leat into a cold Remembrance, will raie Yours into everlating Praie, and force future Ages to peak well of Your Merit.

And were my Performances equal to my Wihes, I might not doubt of a happy Reception; but ince the knowledge of my own weaknes forbids the entertainment of uch thoughts, it waits on Your Grace with all Humility: And whilt You have o much of that Heaven about You, I hall fear little dammage from any Earthly defects of my own.

And Noble Sir, As You are not only the true Heir of the Fortunes, but of the incomparable Worth of o Great a Father, and o Renowned a General, whoe Character being too big for my Pen, I dare leave it to any Impartial Reader of this Age to Judge, whether You do not mot worthily participate with him, both in Your Benign Temper and Honourable Conduct; The delineating of both whoe Heroick Spirits, may well challenge the bet of Orators to decribe; Whoe Goodnes joined with mot noble Qualifications, may as deervedly Entitle You both to that which was once given to the great Emperor Titus: (THE DELIGHTS OF MANKIND.) But why hould I trive to tell the World what they already know, and what I am confident none will Dipute? 'Tis an Honour too great for me, that Your Grace hath (by laying this Command upon me) given me an occaion to publih the hearty deires I have to acknowledge all Your Graces Favours, and to aume a liberty (few Men living but will be proud to hare in) of declaring my elf,

closer.signed: Your Graces, Mot Humble, mot Faithful, And mot Obedient Servant, John Browne.

div.p: LIbrum hunc (cui Titulus Myotomia) Dignum Judicamus, Qui Imprimatur,

div.head: Clarisimis, Doctisimique Viris D. D. Praeidi & Sociis Collegii Regalis Medicorum Londinenium, Myologicam hanc exercitationem ex animo lubens ac merito Dicat Dedicatque, J. Brown.
div.p:
QUantum Lucis Scientiae conferat Methodica Intitutionis ratio, non vobis olummodo (Literatorum Coryphaei) ed & Tyronibus etiam omnibus tam clarum et, quam quod Clarisimum. Partes enim i Debitâ erie tractentur explicenturque, & perpicué abinvicem dignocuntur, & multó melius à Lectoribus percipiuntur; Quippe quod Ordinata rerum dipoitio praecepta, tàm Jucundiora, tàm faciliora reddat, dum ingula eparatim in uâ Clae repoita, memoriam adjuvant & oblectant. Ut igitur ita tam manifeta praetermittam, de re ipâ dicere liceat. Antiquiores hanc Scientiam Anatomicam in duas partes divierunt, Actionem, & Contemplationem, quarum alterius ope, quicquid in Caelo, Terrâ Marique videri uquam poit, in uno homine conpicitur, & tot miracula deteguntur, ut Calamus iis enumerandis oneri uccumberet, & admiratio nos penitus obruat. Nihil et quod vel à Naturâ, vel Arte expectari posit, quod haec Ars non proferat. Subjectum enim ejus adeo nobile et, nimirum Corpus hominis, ad Imaginem Dei, à Deo creati, ut nihil nobilius ub Sole inveniri posit; & ingulas humani corporis particulas adeo eleganter decribit, ut Arti imul vetrae Medicorum, & notrae Chirurgorum
ummo ornamento iet. Veritatem in abditis muculorum (& caeterarum partium) meatibus & tenuisimis fibrillis latentem è Tenebris vindicat, & in clarisimam Lucen revocat. Obcuris Lumen, Oboletis nitorem, Fatiditis gratiam, Dubiis fidem, & vetutate quai abrogatis Authoritatem conciliat: Per hanc Medici ferendo Judicio aptiores fiunt; cum Symptomatibus & indicationibus intructi citius certiuque affirmare queant, quam partem, quâ cauâ morbi dolor, urgeat, afficiatque imò ex ipâ mortuorum diectione dicunt, & vivis hominibus, bonâ valetudine utentibus, vitam denuò intaurare, & moribundus Spiritum, nè exeat, detinere. Et in hâc equidem praxi nulla unquam aetas fuit (ive diligentiam indefeam, ive abundantem Inventorum faelicitatem Spectes) notrâ hac aut ditior aut foecundior; cujus asidua Cura ac Labor improbus nova non pauca adinvenit, antiqua correxit, & hanc artem ita illutravit, ut jam ferè ad culmen perfectionis ummum pervenie videatur. Quod i de Anatomicis videndum eet. Notrates plurimi extiterunt Heroes, qui ut idera Caeli, Clarisima medicinae Lumina, & veluti Dii Mortales in hâc Arte emicuerunt; Inter quos quantâ cum famâ Harvaeius, Entius, Glionius, Whartonus, Charltonus, Willisius, Gualterus Nedhamus, Lowerus, cum multis aliis criperunt, ut Libri & nomina iporum celeberrima nullis delenda aeculis tetantur. Jam tandem ad vos, Viri Apollinei, mea e dirigit Oratio, ub quorum Patrocinio Lucubrationes hace auus um divulgare. De vobis dicere fas et; quod quai Medicorum Principes doctrinae Jatricae fines producitis, & Indutriâ quotidianâ Artem condecoratis, unà & augetis; adeò ut ex Collegio vetro, veluti olo fertili,
Inventa faelicisima ad artis propagationem, & Morborum extirpationem indies nacantur. Ad me quod attinet, Non ita arrogens um, ut aliorum aut dicta, aut facta mihi acribere velim, e potius uum cuique tribuere cupiens, Authorum nomina ad marginem Libri appono, quos in Elencho (eos referente, é quorum criptis univerum hoc opus congetum fuit) Invenietis. Notrum itaque, qualecunque Munuculum, eti non verbis politum, attamen ad utilitatem hominum aliquo modo conducens, (quandoquidem veritatis plurimum in e contineat) fronte erenâ accipite. Valete & Aeternum quam faelicisimi vivite,
div.closer: Sic Orat, Nominib. Illutrib. & Nobillisim. Devotisimus & Obervantisimus, John Brown.

div.head: To his Highly Eteemed Friend Mr. John Browne, &c.
div.p: I Have through want of leiure, but curorily viewed your Hitory of, and Obervations on the Mucles: together with your choice number of their Types and Figures elegantly delineated with your own hand. Yet I think I did it not o uperficially, but that I may truly and confidently ay, that whoever coniders how profitable, and indeed how neceary the knowledge of the Mucles is, not only in Chirurgery, but in Medicine and Philoophy alo, (ince the faculty and ue of the Nerves which ditributes Life and Motion to all parts cannot be undertood and explain'd without it) mut, when he hath perued your Brief, Accurate, and Judicious Treatie, of the Mucles, together with your Obervations and Animadverions thereon, be o Ingenuous, if he be jut, as to acknowledge their great uefulnes not only to Chirurgeons, but to Students in Medicine and Phyloophy likewie, and mut therefore joyn with me to their Encomium; and earnetly deire, and importune their Publication as well as

closer.signed: Your aured Friend and Servant, E. Dickinon M. D. Phyician to the Kings Peron and Family.

div.head: To Mr. John Browne on his Treatie of Mucles.
div.p: I cannot but commend your Ingenuous Deign of making o ueful a Book for the benefit of young Chirurgeons, and your Judicious choice of Cuts for that purpoe: It is a Book which I am ure the Chirurgeons-Hall doth much want, for the younger ort to have in their hands in order to their better attending the Learned Reader. And not only o, but the mot able Anatomits will be glad of o compleat a Contraction of o coniderable part of Anatomy into one view, where they may at any time recollect themelves, as to their former Readings and Obervations. Therefore your Edition of this Treatie cannot but oblige the World, and amongt others,
MYographicum hunc Tractatum ab Expertiimo Viro D. Johanne Browne concriptum, Medicorum Chirurgorumque Tyronibus, & utrorumque etiam Peritiimis utilem fore Judicat,
div.closer: Tho. Allen M. D. Regius Medicus Oridinarius & Coll. Lon. Soc. & Cenor.

div.head: In Laudem Authoris.
div.p: PErlegendo vetrum de Muculis Libellum, magnum invenio certamen inter Ingenium & Ingenioum tui calamum, quis Palmam portare meruit; & nè iniquè Judicarem, Legentibus at erit, tam perutilem, ic perjucundum fore exitimat,

closer.signed: Amicus tuus tui ad Aras, Edvardus Warner. Med. Peronae Regis Ordinarius & ejus Exercitui M. Generalis.

div.head: To his much valued Friend Mr. John Browne.
div.p: I Have read over your Treatie of Mucles, (as my time would permit) and find you have taken great pains and care in your Collections, and made good Obervations, and expret much Art and Indutry in your Figures: and (by conulting excellent Authors) have contracted much into little: that a competent knowledge in this part of Anatomy (o abolutely neceary in the afe practice of Chirurgery) may probably be much eaier attained to, than formerly by young Indagators; and be a further confirmation to others, who have already weat in the ame Study. Therefore I cannot but encourage you to make it publick, by which I uppoe you will oblige many who are Friends to uch Anatomical Enquiries: amongt whom give me leave to reckon,

closer.signed: Your Affectionate Friend To erve you, Edmund King M. D. Phyician in Ordinary to his Majety.

div.head: TO THE Ingenuous and Studious READER.
div.p: AS Anatomy is generally allowed the bet and truet Speculum or Looking-Glas, illutrating, and preenting all the parts of the Body, with their Affects, and Affected Parts, mot clearly and evidently: o alo is it the main Bais, on which Chirurgery doth build its fairet Fabrick, and comely Structure. And of what great ue this hath been, and is, to Mankind, not only the Ancients, but alo Modern Writers do mot admirably declare; How this Renowned Art hath in former Ages been treated, and carefully treaured up and Celebrated in Theaters and Anatomical Schools, many Authors have to Poterity voluminouly atisfied; And that it till doth get greater footing amongt the Ingenuous and Indutrious Sons of Art, every Age doth, and may with admiration evince, and the many Learned Lectures annually read, may both mot honourably and happily et forth and demontrate.

This Art of Anatomy, as it doth require the indutrious Study, and accurate care of a curious Enquiry, o alo doth it reward his pains with the Jewel of Knowledge, and afford his Endeavours the happy iue of a fair ucces: giving thoe methods and meaures of ecurity
in Chirurgical Practice, which are mot conentaneous and genuine for the Indutrious Practitioner, to tudy and earch after. This is as his bet Compas, whereby he may ail freely in the main Ocean of his Art, without any mitrut or dread of plitting himelf upon any Rocks of danger, or Shelves of mitake, for its by this alone, that we arrive at and do gain how our Membranes are made, and pun out of Spermatick Fibres, and how out of Maternal Blood are framed our Mucular parts. It is from this Tree of Knowledge, all the differences between a Vein and Artery are pluckt up: Its this Garden that affords us the various Flowers of Nerves and Tendons, and hews us the different. Beds of Ligaments and Bones: It's this Sun that conducts the ndertanding, that advanceth the ame into Affection, that promotes our Affections towards our Maker. And come we but to take a view and urvey of the ymmetry of his parts, and therein but cat our Eye and conider on the rare Offices and es which are variouly betowed on them, we ought as well in Jutice, as in Reaon, to grant and allow, that nothing in this great nivere may or can urpas him, epecially in the exquiite Fabrick of his Mucles, and the variety of their Motion.

Now although Myology hath been by the Ancients thus traced, yet Steno hath quite altered the Fabrick of their deign, affirming, that there is in every Mucle two oppoite Tendons, into which are inerted two kinds of Fibres, the which being cloely annexed do frame the Tendon, and in that part wherein they are looely intertext, there they do allow of a contituted Fleh, implanting one above another, here placing and dipoing the thicknes and depth of the Fleh, framing its latitude, and declaring its order of Fibres; and this Figure he decribes by a Mathematical Line, taking thence
their Cannons which do explain their actions; Thus he atisfies, that all the Flehy Fibres in a imple Mucle, are carried in a direct Line from one Tendon obliquely into another, and thee Tendons are interwoven in their oppoite ends and angles of the Flehes; Steno's decription of a Mucle. by which he doth ingeniouly decribe a Mucle to be a collection of moving Fibres, o framed and formed, that the middle Flehes do frame an oblique angle, and that the two oppoite Tendons do form two Quadrangular Prima's; this Figure he very accurately repreents by Intruments ued by Painters, or Picture-Drawers, wherein we ee by the application of their Pegs, the true inertion of their Tendons are hereby very well explained, and the Flehy parts lively delineated: for when they bring their greatet ditances from their oppoite angles, and being hereby made more acute, thee are brought to two ides, and o this Intrument is made both longer and narrower, this hewing the Mucle no way contracted, but rather narrowed, and reduced into a longer body, the length thereof not being changed, ave only in its Poition; Thus have we by Steno hewn, a mucle may appear as a imple part coniting of one Venter and two Tendons, as are many of thoe in the Arm, or Thigh, and in many other parts of the Body; or Compound having many Venters, to every of which is allowed two Tendons.

We ought alo to peak omewhat of that Matter which keeps them moit,Humours. and here may we offer, that as touching the Humours by which all the Mucular Fibres, Flehes, Tendons and Membranes are beprinkled and filled, and o hereby een as it were to run into tumefaction, thee are generally reckoned two, (vid.) Blood and Nervous Juyce; As to the firt, this is allowed to tinge and wah over all the Flehy Fibres, and thoe parts to which they are interwoven, and their Membranes, and to often them with manifet ene; Thus if Spirit of Wine tinged with Ink,Ob. be injected into an Artery reaching a Mucle, the Vein being tied up, you will find all the Superficies of the Flehy Fibres, and of its tranvere Fibrilla's to be covered with blacknes, yet will you ee its Tendons carcely concerned with any change of colour, thee only irrigating the Flehy parts, and thoe chiefly which are mot exteriour. How much thee Humours may, and do conduce towards the Animal Faculties and their Exercie is eaily made out: for without this Nervous Liquor, the Animal Spirits would have no proper conitence granted them, and their chief dependance is from their Crais; Hence therefore according to Steno, a perpetual Afflux of Blood is plainly requiite, for as he oberves, in a living Dog, the decendent Trunck of the Aorta or great Artery being tied up without any inciion, the voluntary motion of all the back parts do ceae, o oft as it was tied up, and that the motion renewed o oft as it was relaxed.

Now when the Mucle is contracted, Viviection doth only declare the Flehy Fibres to attain the only motion, as being more tumefied, aperate, and abbreviated, the Mucle welling and enlarging in tis belly, and the inward Tendons as being of themelves immovable, being neither changed in length or thicknes, only drawn up by their Flehy Fibres; whence may be collected, that the Animal Spirits, when they perfect any Mucular motion, they do generally perform this between the Flehy Fibres. Now hall we dicloe ome difficulties which do and may arie as Knotty Diputes about Mucular Diection, and Mucular Motion, and how thee Spirits do operate o tacitely without any incitement thereto; How they fill thee Flehy Fibres, and o eeming to horten their Tendinous Fibres, for the producing of which effects, the plenty of thee Spirits ariing from thee Tendinous Fibres, are not altogether ufficient for performing and managing this, and therefore do require others as its adjutants or aitants to promote and further the ame in its deign, both in occaioning mutual Rarefaction, and Tumefaction, or uddain Inflation of thoe Bodies which do occaion this Abbreviation.

That the Flehy Membrane of the Mucle doth tumefie when its contracted, is without all doubt, and beyond all dipute, for this is apparent enough to ight and touch in Viviection; all the Flehy Fibres being corrugated together, and are more tumefied, and do appear more aperate, hence cometh its abbreviation; the Mucle appearing both more thick and more broad, hence therefore may we jutly conclude, that Mucular Motion in general may probably be granted; As that the Animal Spirits being derived from the Brain by the conduct of the Nerves, and thence conveyed into the body of every Mucle, and from hence by commerce do pas to the
<1 page duplicate>
<1 page duplicate>
Tendinous Fibres, and do at length get quarter there, and entertainment, as in other Promptuaries or Manions, the which Spirits being in their nature very active, o fat as their vigour will permit them, they do expand themelves, and penetrate into the Flehy Fibres: and continuing this their coure, they at length do arrive at the Tendons, and having once entred them, they do therein proceed in the ame method: and that the Animal Spirits flowing from the Tendinous Fibres, do equally pas under the Flehy Fibres, is very apparent; in that it is granted that in every Mucle there is allowed two Tendons, whoe oppoite Angles are o framed, that thee Animal Spirits running from a double top do fill the whole Body of the Mucle; and the motion hence taking its Origination, doth very peedily receed, if the contraction ought to be made indifferently towards the middle Flehy parts: the Tendons are generally equal, but the motion mot inclinable towards one part of the Fleh: and hence may we collect, the regular, or irregular motions of a Mucle, every regular or irregular motion hereof granted to arie from either the Cerebrum or Cerebellum, it being thence dipatcht by the Nerves, and o ent into the Mucles, the effects and conequences whereof do evidently evince and demontrate. Thus have I a little preumed to enlarge upon the Readers Epitle, as touching the ue and benefit of the Mucles, wherein alo I have introduced omewhat of Mucular Motion according to Steno, and have the rather choen to enlarge the Dicoure here, the Body of the Treatie being wholly intended to appear Publick and Concie, without any Flourihes or empty Enlargements of Dicoures or Controveries.
Perue therefore this enuing Dicoure with a Candid Interpretation, and pas by all the Literal Elapes you may meet with, and accept thee with that Amicable Mind, as they are Dedicated and intended by,

closer.dateline: From my Houe at the Chirurgeons-Arms at Charing-Cros, London.

div.head: This Table heweth the Names of the Mucles, as they do arie in Diection.

list.head: Here let the Body be turned upon the Face.
list.item: Nonus humeri Placentini ive Rotundus Minor

list.head: If you intend to take off the whole Arm with the Scapula, the Diection of thee following Mucles will with more eae be performed.
Here you return to the Body it elf as it lies
If you pleae to take off the Thigh from the Trunck of the Body, by dividing the Os Ileon from the Os Sacrum, the diection of the ubequent Mucles will the better be performed.

div.head: The Names of the Authors concerned in this Mucular Dicoure.
Obliquus Decendens.
div.p: THis firt pair of Mucles with which Nature hath covered the Abdomen,This doth laterally compres the Abdomen. as a Vail, are endowed with oblique Fibres, and by reaon of their decent, they have this name betowed upon them. They do arie from the lower parts of the 6th. 7th. 8th. and 9th. Ribs indented; or indenting themelves with Serratus Major Anticus; as alo Membranous from the tranvere procees of the Vertebres of the Loyns, and part of the Os Ileon, and then paing to the Linea Alba, and Os Pubis, by a broad Nervous Tendon marches into the middle of the Abdomen; (its very hard to eparate this Mucle from its ubjacent Tendon without laceration) it adhering o cloely to it.Ob. This Tendon with its next neighbour being either lacerated or dilated, and the Omentum or Intetines hereby making a prolapion either into the Inguen or Scrotum, does occaion either an Hernia Omentalis, or Intetinalis. To diect this Mucle exactly, you mut divide the Latiimus from him very low, o as that you may attain his Lumbal Origination the better.

The chief ue of this Mucle,Its ue. as Columbus and Laurentius do affirm, is to contract the Thorax, as ometimes upwards, hereby aiting Repiration. Laurentius's obervation of thee Mucles is worth note; when he writes that thee Abdominal Mucles are quite contrary to the other Mucles of the Body, thee being crooked before they do Operate, and do turn inward in their Operations, hereby with much facility compreing the inward Cavities; the which, by reaon of the laxnes of the lower Belly, and its yielding to vacuity, it frames a Contention inward,Ob. and a Remiion outwards. Another Obervation may be, that thee Mucles do bind the Intetines in oblique decending Angles.

div.head: The Explanation of the Firt Table.

list.item: B Part of the Mucle called Ani-calptor.
G. G. I. I. K. K K. Muculus obliquus decendens.
G. G. Shews the Flehy part of this Mucle.
a.a.a.a. Shews its Connexion with Serratus Major.
l. l. Shews another part of the ame Mucle.
K. K. K. Shews another Flehy part of this Mucle, with its Tendon and where it begins, and how it is expanded into the Linea alba.
V. V. Shews the Semilunary Line.
L. L. L. The Tendon of the Oblique decendent Mucle running over the right Mucles of the Abdomen to the Linea alba.
M. M. M. The White Line into which this Tendon is inerted.
N. N. N. The Interections of the Right Mucles.
P. P. The Spine of the Os Ileon.
Q. Q. Some heads of the Mucles moving the Thigh.

div.head: Obliquus Acendens.
div.p: THis is immediately ubtrated to the former,This doth help the former in its Compreion. and is furnihed with Acendent Fibres, it arieth flehy from the Appendix of the Os Ileon, and Membranous from the procees of the ame Vertebres as the former; and o acending into the 11th. and 12th. Ribs with a flehy Margent, then extending himelf into a large double Tendon in which the Rectus is conveyed, proceeds to the Linea alba, and Semilunary Line,Ob. and is implanted into the 9th. 10th. 11th. and 12th. Ribs. Oberve that this Mucle is bet rais'd by finding the Nerve that runs between this and the Tranvere at his Origination from Os Ileon.

The chief ue and action of this Mucle as Columbus doth offer,Its ue. is, That thee working together, they do detract the Mucles of the Thorax. Nature planting here a Series of Fibres contrary to the former, and thee being by her thus made for a tronger Compreions.

Moreover as I humbly conceive,Ob. that this Oblique acending Mucle is obliquely perforated near the Os Pubis, by the Crematers and the Spermatick Veins and Arteries a little above the perforation of the Oblique decending Mucles; o that thee Oblique acending Mucles lodging jut under the former, do run counter with them in their Fibres, and do keep them in Oblique acending Angles.

Moreover, that whereas the various Mucles of the Abdomen everal ways contracting themelves inwards, do force the Excrement downwards, and at the ame time do reduce both the Ventricle and Intetines into their proper places, and are Antagonits to the Diaphragma, becaue in its motion in order to enlarge the capacity of the Thorax to give reception to the Lungs tumefied with Air, the Diaphragma is brought towards a plain, and doth thereby both pres the Stomach and Intetines downwards, by which, the motion of the Chyle is gently ollicited into the Ductus chiliferus. And when the Diaphragma hath done playing, thee Abdominal Mucles do act their parts, by relaxing the Diaphragma, and bringing it into an Arch, the Belly growing lank, and the Intetines and Stomach being forc't inwards, and upwards, by the contraction of the Abdominal Mucles.

div.head: The Explanation of the Second Table.

list.item: A A. Obliquus Decendens, laid bare.
B. B. B. The bodies of the Ribs.
a a. a. Shews the Tendinous Membrane of the Oblique decendent Mucle.
B. B. Obliquus acendens, in itu, hewing its Acendent Fibres.
i. i. i. i. Recti Muculi, Tranparent under the Tendons of the Oblique acendent Mucle.

div.head: Rectus.
div.p: THis third pair are cloathed with Right Fibres,This Mucle brings the Belly forwards. being made very trong, and well lin'd with Fleh: They do arie from the Os Pubis, and running according to the length of the Body, are inerted into the ides of the Sternon, where the lat true Ribs have their Cartilages. The Inertions hereof are various, for ometimes there is een three, ometimes four, and ometimes three and a half; ometimes all above, ometimes ome below; as alo the Anatomois, of the Mamillary Veels external, and Epigatrick internal, always found in Women, rarely in Men; as alo the multitude of Nerves ent to the Perigraphs is very obervable, for if you find four Perigraphs, you will find no Pyramidal Mucles.

Thee Mucles are allowed to be of great ue; e. ome Authors affirming that they do abduce the Penis from the Ribs. And when we do arie out of our Beds, thee Mucles do eem to tumefie and fill outwards; others do declare, that thee do inflex the Thorax, and do draw the Bret to the Os Pubis, and the Os Pubis to the Thorax, and that out of their Contraction, there is een two various Motions performed.

But I humbly conceive that thee Mucles taking their Origination from the Os Pubis and Sternon, and inerting themelves into the Linea alba, and running all down in length through the middle of the Abdomen, do in their Contraction pres the Inertions inwards, and do ait the Peritaltick motion in the excluion of groer Excrements.

div.head: The Explanation of the Third Table.

list.item: A A. The Cutis with the Fat laid bare.
D.D.D.D. The Right Mucles of the Abdomen.
e.e.e.e. The Interections of thee Mucles.
L.L. The Oblique Acendant Mucles in ite.
M M. That part of the Tendon of the Oblique Acendant Mucle which covers the Right Mucle.

div.head: Pyramidalis or Succenturiatus.
div.p: THis Mucle hath its name from its make,This preeth the Abdomen downwards. and reemblance it carries with a Pyramidal Figure. It arieth from the external part of the Os Pubis broad and flehy, and running omewhat below the Rectus, is inerted by a long and round Tendon into the Linea alba. Thee Mucles are een ometimes to be wanting in uch Perons as have the Origination of the Acendent Mucle not from the Ileon, but from the trong Ligament which runneth from the Spine up to the Os Pubis, internally: and have four Perigraphs in the Rectus.

Fallopius the Inventer of them,Their e. doth acribe the action of Compreion to them; and that they do promote the Excretion of Urine, this alo he doth affirm. Laurentius does oberve, that if one of thee Mucles doth work alone, it draws the Linea alba obliquely downwards; if they do work together, they do work it directly downwards, and do hereby compres part of the Inguen and the Bladder, when we at leiure do dicharge our Urine. Columbus will have thee Mucles omewhat to add to the Erection of the Penis, but his Opinion is much contradicted by Flud from their Situation: for they cannot reaonably be allowed to erve for this ue, becaue they do in no meaure reach this part, and are alo apparent in Women.

div.head: The Explanation of the Fourth Table.

list.item: A Shews the Mucle Obliquus Acendens
C.C.C.C. The Right Mucle of the Left Side, hewing the Tendons Duplicature.
K.K.K.K. The ame Mucle of the Right Side.
d. The Tranvere Mucle of the Abdomen.

div.head: Tranverus.
div.p: THis fifth Mucle firmly annexed to the adjacent Peritonaeum is framed of Tranvere Fibres,This brings the Abdomen inwards. it arieth from the Tranvere procees of the Loyns and the Os Ileon, and the Cartilaginous inward part of the lower Ribs with a Nervous Membrane, from the ame Ligament as the former; as alo with a Flehy Origination from the inward part of the Spurious Ribs, and Terminates in a broad Tendon at the Semilunary Membranes, the Linea alba, and o down to the Os Pubis; he adheres firmly to the adjacent Peritonaeum in a manner all along, ave only in the Pubes, where he divides himelf. Bartholinus declares, that its chief ue is to Compres the Colon. Its generally agreed by all Anatomits, that thee Mucles do erve for bringing the Abdomen inwards; the which action is very neceary in the Contraction of the lower Belly. Spigelius allows it another action, which is, that it moves the Thorax Circularly to the Sides, hereby promoting and cherihing the Native Heat; Thee Mucles alo being of a moderate thicknes, do erve as a defence and covering to the ubjacent Parts

This Tranvere Mucle is obliquetly perforated a little above the Oblique acending Mucle,O • : by the Crematers, and Spermatick Veins and Arteries; o that the perforations of the Oblique Decending, and Acending Mucles of the Abdomen being framed one above another, not in treight but in bevil Lines, do intercept the paage of the Intetines falling into the Scrotum. Thee Tranvere Mucles running the breadth of the Abdomen cros-ways, do run counter to the Fibres of the Right Mucles, which binds in the Intetines croing the length of the Abdomen downwards long-ways, as the Fibres of the Tranvere Mucles running overthwart, do in their Right Angles ecure the Intetines in their actions broad ways, and cros the Abdomen.

div.head: The Explanation of the Fifth Table.

list.item: A A. The Inward face of the Right Mucles.
B.B. Another of the ame cut in pieces.
e.e. The Pyramidal Mucles laid bare.
F.F. The whole Mucle, Tranveralis in itu.
G.G.G. Nerves ent to this Mucle from the Spinal Marrow.
A.A.A.A. Branches of Veins and Arteries of the Eight Mucle, tranmitted into this Mucles.
h. Shews its Tendon laid bare alo.
K.K.K. Part of the Peritonaeum to which part of this Mucle doth cloely adhere.

div.head: Frontalis.
div.p: HAving cleared all the Abdominal Mucles,This Mucle doth lift up the Forehead. which in neceity did require the firt ue of the Knife: we next come to thoe parts which in order of Dignity do deerve our Inpection; And here begin we with Frontalis, which Mucle doth act variety of potures in Human Bodies, and hereby are excellently delineated the Pictures of Sadnes, Joy, Sorrow, and Mirth, thee being the Paions of the Mind, and are by this Mucle extreamly well Decyphered. This Mucle arieth from the mot elated part of the Forehead, where the Hair ends near the Temporal Mucle, and where the Carnous Membrane adheres mot firmly to the Cranium, and running right down, is inerted into the Skin which covers the Eyes, and into the Eyebrows; In raiing this from the Cranium, you will find Nerves ent from the Cranium to him.

This being raied up, e and Caution. it opens the Eye with it: its framed of Right Fibres, and therefore lies as a good Caution for every young Chyrurgeon that he makes no tranvere Inciion here, let by neglect thereof, he purchae the utter downfall of the upper Eyelid. To this Mucle by late Anatomits are added the two Occipitales which do arie from the middle of the Occiput, e and paing by the Mucles of the Ears, tends to the aforeaid Muculus Frontalis: though thee do not appear o well in all Subjects, yet they do counterpoie in ome meaure. The proper ue of thee is to draw the Skin backward, and to keep the Forehead treight and mooth, that o it may not be too ubject to Wrinkles, by the frequent action of the former.
This Mucle you have very well decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 1. at A. A. at Tab. 7. Fig. 3.
1. At A. Shewing the ame in itu.
a a. Shewing its beginning.
V. V. Its Termination.
A. At Fig. 2. The ame Table hews ame Mucle.

div.head: Aperiens Palpebram Rectus.
div.p: THere are two Eyelids belonging to either Eye,This lifts up the upper Eyelid. the upper of which is moved upwards and downwards, both for the opening and hutting of the ame; the firt de •• gned for Sight, and the econd appointed for maintaining is Vigour. This Mucle arieth from the upper Orbite of the Eye, near its Elevator, where the Optick Nerve hath its tranmiion: ariing with a thin and flehy beginning, and is expanded with a broad and thin Tendon into the Margent of the Palpebra, and taking the ame up, doth open the Eye; this is not to be hewn but with the other Mucles of the Eye after it is taken from the Cranium.O • . This Mucle of the next following, have their ditinct Originations and Inertions, although their Mucular Fibres do eem to unite, which hath •• ade ome Phyicians conclude them to be both but one Mucle; the which on the contrary by acurate Demontration; is hewn that they have two ditinct Nerves taken into two ditinct places; for the upper takes a mall Nerve from that Motion which aries out through the Cavity of the upper Orbite, the lower auming its mall Nerves from that which it produceth through the Cavity of the lower part of the Orbite, the which Phyicians have oberved in a Cymical Spam of the Face: wherein the lower Eyelid is een to appear as it were immoveable, convel'd and drawn downwards, whilt the upper doth move Naturally; The which could not ucceed if they both hould be moved by one Mucle.
This Mucle you have very well explained at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at B. C. and at Tab. 6. Fig. 2. at I. I.

div.head: Claudens eu Semicircularis uperior Deprimens.
div.p: THis arieth with a harp beginning from the inward Angle of the Eye,This huts the Eye. and from part of the Eyebrow near the Noe, and o falls omewhat tranvere towards the Exteriour part of the Eye, becoming flehy, and o broad, as that he poeeth the whole pace between the Eyebrow and the Cartilage out of which the Hairs of the Eyebrow do grow, and is inerted into the Angle of the Eye.

Julius Caerius,
e. Sect. 1. de Organ. cap. 8. doth decribe thee Indications drawn from the Palpebra, as that uch as have their upper Eyelids elated, to be Proud and Fierce; thoe who have them depret, to have their Eyes as it were half hut, thee generally accounted to be of a mild and humble Nature and Dipoition.
This Mucle you have decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 2. at I. I. at B. B. Fig. 1. at the ame Table, and at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at B. and B. Fig. 2.

div.head: Inferior eu Attollens Semicircularis.
div.p: THis arieth being Membranous and thin from the top of the Noe near the Angle of the lower Eyelid,The nether is lifted up by this. with a harp point, and carried tranvere about the middle of the Lid, becoming flehy, and is inerted into the ame Angle as the other. Amongt Authors there is held a Dipute, whether that thee two Mucles be not properly one, and that Orbicularis being o generally received; though the one doth depres, and the other attol or lift up, at the ame time to make a perfect cloe over the Eye.
Thee Mucles are as Drawbridges for the Eye to open and hut; and as the firt doth produce its perfect Sight by being drawn up, o doth the other procure its ready Ret and Quiet by as perfect a cloure.

To thee Riolanus doth add Muculus Ciliaris,
e. which he would have erve to the more firm cloure of the Eyelids; but this depends rather on his Fancy or his Knife, than any Foundation in Nature: nor is there need of uch a Mucle, ince that Office is ufficiently performed by the two forementioned; if they be not one Orbicular Mucle, as ome uppoe, and conequently by their Circular Fibres contringe as firmly as a Sphincter does.
Both thee you have decribed at Fig. 1. Tab. 7. at C. and at B. Fig. 2. in the ame Table.

div.head: Rectus Oculi Primus Elevator.
div.p: THe Curtains of the Eye being drawn,This lifts the Eye upwards we next arrive at the Body of the Eye its elf with its Mucles, by which it performeth all its variety of Motions; the truth is, o much hath already been aid of thee Mucles, as well as of the Coats and Humours which belongeth to the Eye, that its lot time to trouble you with Repetition thereof; this only I hall offer, that this fine Globulous Body ought to have o many Mucles as it enjoys, to make it hang o perpendicularly in the Orbite of its Bone, and be o well ballanc'd, as that it may perform every of its Motions with dexterity, and thereby with eae and advantage execute thoe Offices for which it was at firt deigned.

This Mucle arieth from the upper part of the Orbite of the Eye, near where the Optick Nerve comes forth, and is inerted into that Coat of the Eye called Cornea, where it is clear, and near the Iris by a thin and Membranous Tendon.

This Mucle amongt Anatomits is generally accounted the firt of the Eye, e. and is either called Attollens or Superbus, being held the Mater of Pride and Didain; the expreing of which Action occaions the Eye to open. Dr. Willis Fol. 149. de Anima Brutorum, doth attribute this Motion to the Eyelid rather, and by him is called Muculus Humilis, becaue in a devout and intene Prayer it is much lifted up, and hence is it that we commonly ee the Hypocritical Tribe, who do affect a form of Sanctity to lift their Eyes o much up, that carce any part but the White thereof is een, the Pupil in thee Creatures being o obcured that carce any part therof is to be een.
This you have very well delineated at Tab. 6. Fig. 3. at O. O. and at Fig. 5. in the ame Table at A.

div.head: Rectus Secundus ive Depreor.
div.p: THis is by ome Anatomits called the econd Mucle of the Eye,This brings the Eye downwards. and is o far from advancing it, that it brings it down; and hence hath it the name of Humilis given it, by ome alo it is called Deprimens, hewing by its Action and Motion the Index of an humble and ubmiive Temper and Contitution; it is oppoite to the former, and is leer, ariing from the lower oppoite part of the ame Cavity, and hath its inertions as the former, it brings the Eye towards the Chin; e. This Mucle you have exactly decribed in Tab. 6. Fig. 3. at H. and at D. Fig. the 5th. of the ame Table.

This Mucle is les than the former,Ob. which is its Antagonit Mucle, though their powers hereby are not rendred unequal; becaue there is les force required to depres than to elevate, and therefore we ee it happen in like manner in other parts of the Body. And indeed our great Architect has hereby admirably provided for a due balance of the oppoite Mucles; for where there is an exces of power or action on either ide, we uually ee a Spam ucceed: as happens in the following Mucle, (or Adducens) which in Children is o often contracted by a vitious turning their Eye inward upon drinking, or otherwie, that it occaions that deformed Squinting or cat of the Eye, the which on the account of the Pliablenes of the oppoite Mucle they are o prone to in their tender years, over what they are in a more confirmed Age.

div.head: Rectus Tertius ive Adducens.
div.p: THis third Mucle of the Eye doth arie from the Orbite of the Eye near the Origination of the Elevator,This brings the Eye inwards. ubiting in the inward Angle, drawing the Eye inwards towards the Noe; This Mucle by ome Authors is called Bibitorius, and amongt good Fellows great repect is given to this Mucle, bringing their Eye towards their good Liquor; bringing the Eye towards its inward Angle, and making it hereby look omewhat a Squint.Ob. Dr. Willis in his Book De Anima Brutor. cap. 15. de Viu, makes mention of a Young man troubled with the Palie, who when his other Mucles of his left Eye were relaxed, this Adducens was trongly contracted, and hence his Eye was o ditorted, that its Object eemed as it were double, neither could he ditinguih any thing very well with it.
This Mucle you have excellently decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 2. at G. at Fig. 3. at I. I. in the ame Table, and alo at Fig. 5. of the ame Table at B.

div.head: Rectus Quartus ive Abducens.
div.p: THis Mucle by Anatomits is ometimes called Abducens, This brings the Eye outwards. and likewie Indignatorius, from its cros and cornful Effects it carries with it, bringing the Eye outwards. This Mucle arieth from the External Angle of the Eye, and is inerted as the former: the Eye is drawn inwards by thee four working together, and the motion is as it were upended, which by Phyicians is called a Tonick Motion. In Diection of a Monkey,Ob. all thee Mucles perfectly appeared exactly as in a Human Eye: and which is obervable in thee Creatures ditinguihable from all other Bruits, thee have no Muculus Supenorius, or Septimus Brutorum.
This Mucle you have alo exactly decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 2. at H. and at K. K. Fig. 3. and at C. Fig. 5. of the ame Table.

div.head: Obliquus Minor ive Inferior.
div.p: THis Mucle arieth from a Chink which is in the lower part of the Orbite of the Eye,This brings the Eye towards its External Angle. in his Origination Flehy, mall, and not altogether round, and is c • rried Obliquely in his whole coure, and acending by degrees to the upper part of the Eye, is there inerted by a hort but Nervous Tendon, near the Tendon of the Abducent Mucle; not far off which, the Tendon of the other Oblique Mucle hath alo its inertion, e. and by moving the Eye downwards it doth convert and abduce it towards its External Angle in a rowling manner.

This Mucle alo you have decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 3. at
• . and at Fig. 5. at E. in the ame Table.

div.head: Obliquus Major vel Superior cum Trochlea.
div.p: THis arieth from the ame place with the Abducent, This carries the Eye to its inward Angle. and marcheth in a right Line to the External part of the Internal Angle, where it grows indifferently thick, and is then attenuated and grows round, and goes through a Pulley there deigned for it, the which o oon as it hath pat it, it, yet o bends its elf that it makes the Right Angle of the Eye; and running upwards it begins to grow Oblique, and paing by the Levator is inerted between the Abducent and Oblique Mucles, as is before demontrated. The Trochlea or Pully is a perforated Cartilage, paing to the Bone of the upper Mandible, near the inward Angle of the Eye; Thee two Mucles are called Amatorii, or the Lovers Mucles, being as the true Meengers of Affection, by ome they are called Circumactores or the Rowling Mucles, for they do much work in Human Body; in Sheep alo they are of very great ue, being given them as their chief Watchers, or thoe which do work their Eyes about. The young Chyrurgeon is here cautioned, that in his Curing of Fitula Lachrimalis, Caution. he takes great care of this Mucle. The ue of this Mucle is to turn or rowl the Eye inwards towards the inward Angle of the Eye by a Circular Motion, e. and o to abduce the Pupil from the Nares or Notrils;Ob. everal Fibres do pas from the Periotium, or inward Film of the Orbite to the forementioned Trochlea, and according to ome do contitute the Muculus Trochleae, though the ue of them eem deigned for a teddy fixing the Trochlea, rather than for a Mucular motion.

This Mucle you have alo exactly decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 2. at D. E. F. D. hewing the Mucle E. the Trochlea, and F. the chord of this Mucle; at Fig. 3. at M. M. you have it, and at E. Fig 5. you have it again very exactly delineated.

div.head: Attollens Aurem.
div.p: AS the Eyes are placed in the forepart of the Head as Watchmen to guard the Body,This carries the Ear upwards and forwards. o alo hath our wie Creator planted two Ears at the ides thereof for the better perception of Sounds, and a more ready paage to hearing, to the better performance of which there are hereto given variety of Mucles; amongt which, this is reckoned as the firt, it ariing from the External Termination of the Frontal Mucle, and o being thin and Membranous, is carried over the Temporal Mucle, and is inerted growing narrower into the upper part of the Ear, e. moving it upwards and forwards
This Mucle you have exactly delineated at Tab. 6. Fig. 4. at H. and at S. Tab. 7. Fig. 1. you have the ame again.

div.head: Detrahens Aurem.
div.p:
THis Mucle arieth Flehy,This moves the Ear downwards. broad, and ometimes Fibrous, from the back part of the Head, near the Mamillary proces, and o growing narrower in its progres is inerted into the whole Cartilage which encompaeth the Ear; be careful in raiing the Cutis let you take up this Mucle with it, and o looe him; this moves the Ear downwards and forwards, this Mucle is by ome allowed as part of Quadratus Buccas De rahens.
e.
This you have hewn you at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at T. T. T.

div.head: Adducens Aurem ad Anteriora.
div.p: THis is a common Mucle,This draws the Ear forwards. being part of that which Spigelius calls Quadratus Buccas Detrahens, and is alo allowed as part of that Mucle called Platuma Myodes, from whoe inertion you will find a Flehy and Fibrous Elongation implanted into the Root of the Ear

This Mucle is aid to draw the Ear forwards and omewhat upwards. Expect to meet this at Quadratus Buccas Detrahens,
e. as being a part of it.

div.head: Abducens Aurem ad Poteriora.
div.p: THis Mucle is planted at the Occiput, This brings the Ear backwards. and arieth above the Mamillary procees from a Knot of Mucles which belong to the Occiput, with a narrow beginning, and being carried downwards tranverely, is inerted with a double and ometimes treble Tendon into the hinder part of the Ear. This Mucle is aid to draw the Ear backwards: In Beats, as in Hores, Oxen, and the like Bruits thee Mucles are much more large and apparent, and oft times more numerous, whence it is, that thee can move their Ears more powerfully, and act thoe trong motions with them which we ee is cutomary for them to do.
This you have decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 4. at I. I. I.

div.head: Externus Tympani Auris.
div.p: THe inward Ear hath two Mucles allowed it,This brings the Tympanum upwards and forwards. found our by the two excellent Anatomits Hieronimus Fabritius de aqua pendente, & Julius Caerius Placentinus, and of thee one is planted <> , the other inwards; and from hence they do take the •• names; this arieth from the upper and inward paage of <> Auditory paage with a large Origination, and becoming • ehy is inerted externally by a hort Tendon into the Tympanum, extending the Membrane with the Malleus upwards and outwards. e. Spigelius aith it is mall and arieth from the Culis, and that Membrane which covers the Auditory paage.

This Mucle is one of the leat in the whole Body, and is to be hown entire with ome difficulty;
<>
great caution therefore is to be ued <> opening the Os Petroum, about that part which repects the Temples, whether it be done by the mall Chi • l or filing, <> o the pieces of Bones being taken out by degrees, this Mu ••• may receive no prejudice; the like car •
is to be oberved alo in hewing the following Mucle.
This Mucle you have exactly hewn you at Tab. 6. Fig. 6. at A.

div.head: Internus Tympani Auris.
div.p: THis Mucle is inwardly planted,This brings it obliquely forwards and omewhat inwards. eated in the Os Petroum, having its Origination from the Bais of the Os Cuneiforme, and o becoming Flehy, though thin and mall, and having made half his progres, divides himelf into two very mall and very thin Tendons, the one of which is implanted into the upper proces of the Malleus, the other into the Neck thereof, drawing it obliquely forwards, and bringing it omewhat inwards.

Thee two Mucles do then firt move the Membrane with its mall Bones upwards and downwards, e. when we would carefully liten or hearken to any important Matter, &c. Matter or Concern, as Diemerbroeck oberves. Dr. Willis Fol. 133. de Anima Brutorum, Ob. writes, that the action of this Mucle is involuntary, and is wrought about by ome Intinct of Nature; for when a very vehement ound doth approach the Ears, this Mucle doth remit its great noie, o as that it does enibly obtund the relaxed Tympanum more powerfully; but if it be either more thin, or more obtue, this contracted Mucle doth ditend the Tympanum, o that this obtue Impreion may be made more enible.
This Mucle alo you have exactly decribed at Tab. 6. Fig. 6. at C. C.

B. B. The Mucles of the Eyelids.
b. c. The Membrana Carnoa laid bare.

list.head: FIG. II.

F. The Chord of this Mucle.
I. I. The Mucle of the upper Eyelid.
K. K. Shews them cut off.

list.head: FIG. III.

B. B. Part of the Brain.
D. The uniting of the Optick Nerves.
E. E. Their progres to the Eyes.
H. Deprimens of the Right Eye.

list.head: FIG. IV.
list.item: H. Muculus Auriculam recta uru • Movens.
I. I. I. Muculus Triceps eandem urum trahens.

list.head: FIG. V.

div.head: Abducens Nai Alas.
div.p: THe Noe is the Organ of Smelling,This dilates <> Noe. and this gains place in the more eminent part of the Body, for the better uception of the acent of Vapours and inviible Halations, and their Qualities are ent up hither by the Olfactory Nerves to the common Senory, and are there approved of according to Judgment; and thus is Man brought into a capacity of either taking or refuing uch things as may prove either beneficial or prejudicial, purchaed without the Eye, and perceived without the Ear; The Noe is not wholly moved, but rather its lower parts which we call Alae, and thee are either kept open or hut by the benefit of Mucles: and thee are called either Abducentes or Adducentes, or if you pleae Aperientes or Claudentes.

This Mucle arieth very mall and Flehy from Os Maxillae Superioris, near the firt Par Labiorum proprium, and is inerted into the lower and upper part of the Alae,
e. and moveth either part upwards.
This you have exactly delineated at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at D. in •• , c. hews its Origination, d. its Inertion Fig. 2. id. Tab. you have the ame at B.

div.head: Attollens Nai Alas.
div.p:
THis Mucle arieth from the top of the Bone of the Noe,This brings it upwards. near the Lachrymal Cavity, with a harp and Flehy beginning, decending to its ides in a triangular form much reembling the Greek Letter < in non-Latin alphabet > and o decending according to the length of that Bone, is inerted broad and Flehy into the Alas Nai, and do carry the ame upwards; Caerius hath found them much reembling Myrtle Leaves, thee two pair drawing the Nai Alas,
e. do dilate and open the Notrils.
This you have fairly decribed at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at E. e. hewing its harp and Flehy beginning, f hewing its Termination into the Alas, B. hews the ame in the ame Table Fig. 2.

div.head: Claudens Naum Externus.
div.p: THee Mucles are very mall,This Mucle huts the Notrils. and without it happen in very Naute Perons they are never een or to be ditinguihed; the firt pair of which is outwards and Flehy, and o do arie at the Root of the Alae, and o climbing tranverely is inerted into the tip of the Noe; and as Velingius judgeth, e. doth dilate the ame, whilt others do affirm that this doth contringe it.
Thee Mucles are not to be hewn by any Figure, being both o mall, and o inwardly implanted.

div.head: Claudens Naum Internus.
div.p: THis is much like the former as to its bignes,This doth contringe the Noe inwards. lodging inwardly under the Membrane which covereth the Noe from the Bone, it arieth from the end of the Bone of the Noe, and is expanded into the Alam Nai, and doth contringe it; this is very mall, and very rarely found out, unles in uch Naute Perons whoe general Series of Mucles are very apparent, thicker, and larger than ordinary.

There is alo another Contrictive Mucle, which hath gotten the name of Orbicularis common to the upper • ip, the which drawing the • ip downwards, doth alo therewith hut up and cloe the Notrils; And this Bartholinus decribes in Fol. 358. Anatom. where he affirms, That he hath oberved an Appendix hereof to decend to the upper Lip, and that in uch People who could not lift up their Noe without their Lips.
This Mucle with its former is not to be hewn by Figures, they being o very mall.

div.head: Zygomaticus Riolani, vel Attollens Labium Superius.
div.p: TO Man are given Lips,This lifts up the Lip. both for his accommodation of Eating and Drinking; as alo for forming his Voice, retention of Spettle, hutting the Mouth and defending the ame from outward Injuries; and becaue all thee Qualifications do require a voluntary Motion, they have given to them variety of Mucles to perform the ame: amongt which this is nominated one of the third proper pair called by Riolan. Zygomaticus.

It arieth Flehy from the Os Sygoma, with a Flehy and broad beginning, and running obliquely downwards and forwards is inerted into the ide of the upper Lip near Primus Nai, the which doth abduce it to its ides upwards. See this Riolanus Anatomy.
This alo you have hewn you at the Letter G. at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. and at Fig 2. id. Tab. at C. you have the ame.

div.head: Abducens Labia.
div.p: THis arieth from the Os Zygoma Flehy and round with much Fat,This brings the Lip upwards and outwards. and is implanted into the Lips where they are joyned together: this moves the Lips upwards and outwards, e. and doth alo help the former in their motion; this by ome Anatomits is accounted the firt proper pair: thee Mucles do alo draw the Lips to the ide, whether either one or both do operate either ingly or together.
This Mucle you have hewn in itu, at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at H. i. and k. hewing both its Origination and Inertion; the ame you have at the Letter D. in the econd Figure of the ame Table.

div.head: Labium inferius Deprimens.
div.p: THis arieth Flehy from the lowermot and outermot part of the lower Mandible,This brings the lower Lip downwards and outwards. whence running obliquely, it is broadly inerted into the middle of the Lip, and moves it downwards and outwards; this is called the fourth pair of the proper Mucles.

This Mucle hath a part with the firt pair called Detrahens Quadratus, by which it is obliquely moved to either ide, (vid.) right or left, as either of them are in Operation, drawing the whole lower Lip downwards.

This Mucle you have hewn at the Letter I. Tab.
e. 7. Fig. 1. and at E. in the econd Figure of the ame Table.

div.head: Par Labium contringens ive Muculus Orbicularis & Contrictor.
div.p: THis is common to either Lip,The Lips are pured up by this. being framed of a fungous Subtance, with Orbicular or Contrictory Fibres, ariing from the middle of the Bones of the upper and lower Mandible, and doth form and make the whole Body of the Lips, encompaing the Mouth like a Sphincter, and drawing the Lips mutually to it, the which do firmly adhere to the red Cutis, which gives them their admirable Vermilion Dye; as alo hews the Palenes of them in Sicknes; All thee Mucles of the Lips are o cloely conjoyned to the Cutis, that their Fibres do interect one amongt another; and hence is it that uch a variety of motions are een in the Lips; and thus have we hewn all the Mucles of the Lips. Fallopius hath another pair of thee Mucles belonging to the Lips, whoe Cutis is o cloely mixed with the Mucles, that it rather eems to be a Muculous Cutis or a Cuticular Mucle.
This Mucle is alo called Oculatorius from the ue which is made of it. e.

Thee Mucles of the Lips have variety of Ues given them for performing their diverity of Actions; as ome being deigned for hutting the Mouth, others for opening the ame: ome made for accommodation of Eating and Drinking, and others formed for Ornament of Speech and Love Motions.
This you have fairly hewn you at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at K. K. and at Tab. id. Fig. 2. you have the ame at F. F.

div.head: Quadratus ive Platyma Myodes.
div.p: THe firt Mucle lying under the Skin of the Neck is called Quadratus, This draws down the Che • k. from its Figure, and is mall and Membranous firmly adhering to the Cutis, ariing from the Vertebres of the Neck, Scapula, Clavicle, and Sternon, large, broad and thin, with tore of Membranous Fibres, and o running up with oblique Fibres, is inerted into the Chin, where both the upper and lower Lips are joyned; and enlargeth himelf o far as to make Adductor auris ad Anteriora and becaue it agrees much with the Chin, it helps forwards the opening of the Mouth; and by its enlarging its elf o far as to make Adductor auris ad Anteriora, the Ears alo may be allowed to be moved by the help of this Mucle; it hath various Surcules of mall Nerves belonging to it from thoe of the Neck; This Mucle being once convelled there follows a Cynick Spam.

Here's Caution alo for the young Chyrurgeon,Caution. where he ought to take notice of the Fibres of this Mucle, epecially when he may or hall be called to make Inciion here; for want of knowing of which upon making tranvere Inciions here, and croing the Fibres and their Ductures, he preently occaions an Avulion in the Cheeks, otherwie great care mut be had to preerve this Mucle; for whether you do raie the Cutis from above or below, he adheres very cloely to it; In the raiing this Mucle, be careful of leaving its Elongation that makes Adductor auris ad Anteriora, which you will rarely mis.
This Mucle according to Riolanus you have expreed in our 10th. Tab. Fig. 1. at F.

div.head: Buccinator.
div.p: THis econd Mucle which formeth the Cheek is called Buccinator from the ue that is made of it;This draws the Cheek inwards. it arieth from the upper part of the upper Mandible, and from the lower part of the lower Mandible, where the Gums begin, and do amplect the whole Cheeks in their eats, being round like a Circle: the proper Coat of the Mouth adheres o firmly to him inwards, that he is carce eparab • e from it; outwardly he hath a large round Tendon implanted into the midt of him, which hath his Origination from a Glandalous Subtance, growing to the Os Zygoma, cloe by the Origination of the Mucle o called.

This Mucle doth not only move the Cheeks with the • ips, e. but doth alo contringe them, and drive the Meat fallen into the Mouth into the Cheeks back again to the Teeth, ending or conveying the Meat thither, until it be better leened, and made maller, and a more accurate Confraction of the ame be hereby made. Placentinus writes, That he hath found a very trong Ligament in the Center of this Mucle; the which ariing outwards, and creeping along the Os Gingivae, terminateth into a mall and thin Mucle directly oppoite to the Cheek; but Riolanus denies the ame.
This Mucle if you pleae may alo be allowed as a hand to the Teeth, e. ending the Meat till it be well Chewed to the Teeth, by which it may the be • ter be leened and comminuted.
This Mucle you have hewn you at Tab 7. Fig. 1. at F. and at P. Tab. ead. Fig. 2.

div.head: Maeter ive Lateralis, eu Manorius.
div.p: THis arieth with a double beginning,This draws then th • r Mandible latera • y. trong, large, and Nervous; firt from that Suture where the fourth and firt Bone of the upper Mandible joyneth; econdly Flehy from the Os Jugale, and is firmly and largely inerted into the lower Mandible External; e. This Mucle by reaon of its diverity of Fibres given it, doth move the nether Mandible forwards, backwards, and laterally, and • s it were about alo; If you throw this Mucle either from its Origination o • Inertion, Temporalis will appear in its Inertion.
The proper Ue of this Mucle is hewn in Matication; e. it moves to both ides, as to Right and Left; it takes its name of Manorius from its proper Action: and from its ite, it is called Lateralis.
This you have hewn you at Tab. 7. Fig 1. at the • etter O. I. hews it alo at Fig. 2. Tab. ead. where b. b. hews its Origination, and c. c. its Inertion.

div.head: Temporalis eu Crotaphites.
div.p: THis is the firt and tronget of all the Mucles,T ••• draws the Mandible upwards. filling the whole Cavity of the Temple Bones; it arie • h from the Os Frontis, Syncipitis, & Sphaenoides, flehy and Semicircular, and growing narrower in his de •• ntion, runneth under Os Jugale, with a hort but very trong and flehy Tendon into the proces of the lower Mandible called Corone; it hath allowed it three Nerves on either ide: One from the third, a econd from the fourth, and a third from the fifth pair; e. Wherefore this Mucle being either inflamed, contued or wounded, harp pains do immediately ucceed, and great danger of Convulion and fear of Death, epecially if the hurt do happen about the Nervous part thereof; As touching the Periotium, you will find that if you do raie this Mucle carefully, (contrary to the opinion of ome) you will meet it under this Mucle, although many have aerted the contrary. The end of this Mucle is the beginning of the lower Mandible, the which it moves and draws upwards, and hereby hutteth the mouth; and by ome hence it is called Attollens, and is the tronget Mucle of the Body in repect of its bulk. And as Spigelius writes, it is furnihed with o much trength, that he remembers in his ripe years that he hath lifted up everal pounds of Lead by the trength of his Teeth, and carried them therewith. I have een very great weights brought from the ground by the Teeth and trength of this Mucle, and it has been reported above 200l weight has been lifted from the ground by them. This Mucle both huts the Mouth, and contringes the Teeth.

In opening the Temporal Artery, e. caution is to be ued by the young Chirurgeon let he injureth this Mucle,Ob. by cutting too deep, whence fatal Convulions (or at leat a prejudice to Matication) do ucceed. The afet way therefore is, firt to make a light inciion of the Skin, and then the Artery lying bare may the readier be hit and divided without injuring this Mucle, which lies under it; or at leat it will be well to ue in this Operation the Lancet that is retue on one ide like the Penknife, and to take the Artery pretty high about that part of the Temples which joyns to the Os Frontis.
This you have at Tab. 7. Fig. 1. at L m. m. m. hewing its Semicircular beginning, H. hews the ame, Fig. 2. ejud. Tabal.

div.head: Matoideus.
div.p: THis is one of the eight pair eated in the forepart of the Neck,This contracts the Neck. trong, long, and mooth: it arieth with a double beginning; a certain Cavity ditinguihing them, one from the Sternon Nervous, and the other Flehy from the more elated part of the Clavicle, and is obliquely inerted into the Mammillary proces by a round and Flehy Tendon.

This is worthy Note,Ob. that in a live Man, epecially in thin and aged People, in which it is very conpicuons, that if the whole pair do work, e. it bends the Head right, but if one of them do only work, this Mucle is only contracted, and this brings the Head forward laterally.
This you have at Tab. 7. Fig. 2. at K in itu, d. d. hewing its Origination from the Sternon, e. e. its Inertion into the Mammillary proces of the Temple Bone.

div.head: Biventer Digatricus eu Graphyoides.
div.p: THis is the econd pair called Biventer, This draws the Mandible downwards and opens <> Mouth. the like of which is not to be found in Human Body; in the middle of whoe Venter it groweth thinner, having as it were two Venters, ariing near the Mammiform proces: it arieth with a broad and Nervous beginning from the proces Styloides, and uddenly becoming round, Flehy, and mall, o oon as he recurvates under the Styloides, he becomes a Nervous round Tendon, and then becomes Flehy again, and is inerted into the middle Interiour part of the nether Mandible, and by drawing the Mandible downwards doth open the Mouth; the too great decent of which is hindred by its annexed Ligament. And for the better performance of this work, the former Mucle doth help this very much in its Operation.

Provident Nature hath given this Mucle two Bellies,Ob. and from thence it got its name, having in its middle an interjacent Tendon, very aptly reembling a Trochlea or Pulley; formed for this ue, that whereas thee Mucles do not arie from the lower parts of the Neck, but rather bred from the upper parts thereof; they do reflect about the lower parts of the Mandible like a Pulley, drawing the Mandible downwards, and o opening the Mouth.
This you have hewn at Tab 7. Fig. 1. at N. Extra Situm, whoe Tendon is decribed by N. and its Venters by L. M.

div.head: Coracohyoides.
div.p:
THis Mucle is very thin and lon,This brings the Os Hyoides obliquely downwards. o that by Anatomits it is held there is not its like to be found in Human Body, for thinnes and length; it is endowed with a double Belly by a ditinct Tendon: it arieth with a Flehy beginning near the Neck of the Os Scapulae from its proces Coracoides, and running under the Levator Patientiae of the Scapula, is obliquely carried under the Matoides, and there becometh a mall round Tendon, and then Flehy again: and o is implanted into the Horns of the Os Hyoides,
e. and draws it obliquely downwards; If you leave this Mucle in its Origination at the Diection of the Levator, you will find his Origination perfect.
This Mucle hath a double Venter,Ob. as its former Companion, that the Jugular might not be too much compret by it.

This you have decribed very exactly at Tab. 7. Fig. 2. at the Letters L. L. thee two Letters demontrating its two Venters decribed in their Natural Poition; and at Tab. 8. Fig. 3. you have the ame laid bare at H. H.

list.head: The Explanation of the Seventh Table.
FIG. I.
list.item: A The Frontal Mucle in itu.
b. b. Its end or Termination.
B. C. The Mucle of the Palpebrae.
e. f. Shews its beginning and ending.
i. k. Shews its beginning and ending.
H. Shews the econd pair, Abducens Labia.
i. k. Its beginning and ending.
m. m. m. Shews its Semicircular beginning.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: B. B. The Mucles of the Palpebrae.
Ae. Nai Alas Contringens in itu.
b. b. Shews its two beginnings.
c. c. Shews its inertion into the largenes of the lower Mandible.
d. d. Shews its beginning from the Sternon.
e. d. Its inertion into the Mammillary proces.

div.head: Sternohyoides.
div.p: THee are generally accounted the econd pair,This brings the Os Hyoid • s downdownwards. moving the Os Hyoides downwards and backwards; This Mucle arieth broad and Flehy from the inner part of the Sternon under the Skin of the Neck, and running on (the ame in ubtance and breadth all along) the Apera Arteria, and the Thyreoidal Cartilage of the Larynx, is inerted into the Bais of the Os Hyoides.
This Mucle brings the Os Hyoides directly downwards and omewhat backwards. e.
You have this fairly delineated at Tab. 8. Fig. 2. at C. C. and at G. G. Fig. 3. id. Tab.

div.head: Sternothyreoides.
div.p: THee Mucles of the Larynx (as they call the Head of the Aperia Arteria) are o nominated,This extends the Larynx. not becaue they do move the whole Larynx, but its Cartilages; This formerly was called Bronchus, but we more properly from its name and inertion do call it Sternothyreoides: it arieth Flehy and broad from the upper and inner part of the Sternon, and keeping his dimenions, creeps up with treight. Fibres along by the Apera Arteria, and is inerted into the lower ide of the Scutiformal Cartilage, the which when it prees the Scutiformis, it narrows its Rima or Cleft.

It is generally believed that this does cloe up the lower part of the Scutiformis,
e. and that it draws downwards, whence the upper part thereof is een to be extended, and the Rimula or Cleft dilated.
This alo have you delineated at Tab. 8. Fig. 2. at L. L. N. N. hews the ame at Fig. 3. Tab. ejud.

div.head: Hyothyreoides.
div.p: THis arieth from the whole ide of the Os Hyoides, This contra • s the La • ynx. at his Bais, and running down broad with right Fibres is inerted into the lowet and lateral part of the Scutiformal Cartilage, and by attolling it, doth dilate its Rima. Riolanus thought this pair not to be peculiarly appointed to any Cartilage, but did lift up the whole Larynx; if you raie this Mucle clear from its Origination and Inertion, you will be les troubled to find out thee Mucles of the Larynx.

This draws the Larynx upwards,Ob. whence it is we in our elves, when we would frame a harp Voice, that we then do bring the Larynx upwards, and when this is contracted, it contracts the upper part of the Scutiformis, driving it inwards.
This alo you have delineated at Tab. 8. Fig. 2. at m. m. M. M. hewing the ame at Fig. 3. ejud. Tab.

div.head: Styloceratohyoides.
div.p: THis third pair arieth from the Root of the Proceus Styloides, This brings the Os Hyoides obliquely • ipwards. and being mall and round, is implanted into the Horn of the Os Hyoides, found infallibly by Digatricus his running through or under him, obliquely, moving the Os Hyoides obliquely upwards.
This draws it obliquely upwards. e.
Oberve that its Inertion is in the lower part of the Horn (or rather towards the Bais) of the Os Hyoides.
E. E. Shews this, Tab. 8. Fig. 3. F. F. Shews the ame, ead. Tab. Fig. 2.

Amongt thee Mucles of the Fauces, §. the two pair lately found out by the Ingenious Doctor Croune may not improperly here be mentioned; one of which are named by him Muculi Pterygo-palatini, and the other Spheno-palatini. The former of thee are eated in the Interior part of the Cavity of the Os Pterygoides, and terminate with their Tendons (which run on part of the foremention'd Bone as on a Trochlea) about the Glandula palati, which (together with the Uvula) they depres.

The latter of thee, or Spheno-palatini, arie from the Os Sphenoides, and with a broader Tendon are inerted into the ides of the Glandula palati, which (together with the Uvula) they do attoll. From the ituation and action of thee latter Mucles may ome account be given, how the Uvula being relaxt is commonly reduc't by thruting the Thumb bent toward the Palate or thee Mucles.
Thee Mucles you have exactly hewn you at Tab. 10. Fig. 2. at O. O. X. X. Shews its Tendon, Q. Shews the latter, where f. f. hews its Tendon alo.

div.head: Mylohyoides Riolani.
div.p: THis arieth laterally from the nether Mandible inwards,This moves the Os Hyoides directly upwards. under the Dentes Molares, Flehy, and is inerted into the Bais of the Os Hyoides, externally; this is to be thrown upwards in Diection. Look into Riolan. which doth give you atisfaction as to this Mucle.

div.head: Styloceratohyoides.
div.p: THis third pair arieth from the Root of the Proceus Styloides, This brings the Os Hyoides obliquely upwards. and being mall and round is implanted into the Horn of the Os Hyoides, found infallibly by Digatricus, his running through, or under him moving the Os Hyoides obliquely upwards;. Oberve that its inertion is in the lower part of the Horn, or rather towards the Bais of the Os Hyoides.
This draws it obliquely upwards. e.
This you have hewn you at Tab. 8. Fig. 2. at E. E. F. F. hewing the ame at Fig. 3. ejud. Tabul.

div.head: Myloglous.
div.p: THe Tongue,This moves the Tongue upwards. whereas it is not only the primary Intrument of the Voice, but alo is ueful for turning of the Meat contained in the Mouth, and doth obtain very many voluntary Motions; for the executing of each of which, there are required everal Mucles, amongt which this is aid to be the fourth pair, it arieth with a broad beginning from the innermot lateral part of the lower Mandible under the Molares, and is inerted into the Ligament which ties the Bais of the Tongue to the Fauces; At the Origination of Mylohyoides you will certainly find this, and it is bet hewn when the Mandible is divided: when one of thee move, the Tongue is turned upwards: when both move, the tip is directly lifted upwards towards the Palate.
C. Shews this Mucle, Tab. 8. Fig. 2.

div.head: Ceratoglous.
div.p: THis is one of the four pair ariing from the Horns of the Os Hyoides, This brings the Tongue downwards. and hence it is called Ceratoglous, and is implanted obliquely into the ides of the Tongue, near its Root; e. if both thee work together, they draw the Tongue downwards and inwards: if only one operate, it moves it either to the right or left ide.
I. Shews this, Tab. 8. Fig. 3. D. Shews the ame, Fig. 2. ejud. Tab.

div.head: Genioglous.
div.p: THis is one of the econd pair o called by Spigelius: This moves it forward • . it arieth with a narrow Origination, about the middle of the lower Mandible or Chin, and then enlarging himelf, is inerted into the Root of the Tongue; Velingius doth number this amongt the number of Os Hyoides, and aith that they are implanted at the Bais of the Bone, which it draws treight upwards, e. whereby the Tongue is the more eaily thrut forward out of the Mouth, though in the exceive heat of Fevers, the Fibres of this Mucle are o parcht that the Patient does it with difficulty.
E. Shews this, Tab. 8. Fig. 3.

div.head: Hypiloglous eu Baioglous.
div.p: THis is one of the third pair,This moves it backwards. it arieth Flehy from the Bais of Os Hyoides, and is inerted into the middle of the Tongue, according to its longitude, and by drawing it inwards, e. doth bring it backwards.
This being contracted, it brings the Tongue inwards, and backwards.
G. Shews this, Fig. 3. Tab. 8.

div.head: Styloglous.
div.p: THis arieth Flehy and mall,This brings the Tongue upon upwards inwards. with a harp beginning from the Styloidal proces, and growing more broad and Flehy, is inerted into the lateral part of the Tongue, and it brings it upwards and inwards: it is bet found, by dicovering of Styloides with your Finger, and then your Eye will direct you to it, at the lateral part of the Tongue; in man it is lender, but in Beats it is double, Flehy, and thick.
Its ue is thus explained; e. If either of thee Mucles moves, the Tongue is carried either to the right or left ide directly, but both moving, its brought back to the Fauces.
K. Shews this, Tab. 8. Fig. 3.

div.head: Lingualis.
