div.p: THis arieth Flehy and large from the Bais of the Os Hyoides, This moves the Tongue both in Contriction and Dilatation. and o runs according to its longitude, forward to the tip of the Tongue, and is much diputable whether it be a Mucle or not; it's endowed both with oblique, tranvere, and right Fibres, all which are o fully prinkled about the Tongue, that is through its whole Body, that they are carce diviible, and cannot by the bet and mot indutrious hand be eparated.

Spigelius doth give thee Ues to thee pair of Mucles, e. if they may properly be called o, that the tranvere Fibres which are implanted in them do erve to contract the Body of the Tongue and o to thicken it, the oblique <…> and eparating them from one another, and that the <…> framed for bringing it to the Palate and Fauces in <…> .
This Mucle is not to be explained, being diputable whether it be a Mucle or not amongt Anatomits.

div.head: Cricothyreoides Anticus.
div.p: THis is aid to be the firt proper pair of the Larynx, This moves the Cartilage obliquely downwards. as is held by Velingius and mot Anatomits: it takes its Origination from the fore-part of the Annulary Cartilage, and ends in the ides of the Scutiformal, and hence it gets the name of Cricothyreoides Anticus, and is generally reputed to move the Cartilage omewhat obliquely downwards; it arieth in the lower and fore-part of the Larynx, having a Flehy beginning; when this is contracted, e. it extends the Cartilage Cricois or Annularis, and o openeth its Cleft for a more deep and greater Voice or Sound.
F. Shews this at Tab. 8. Fig. 2. D. D. Shews the ame laid bare, Tab. ead. Fig. 2. C. Shews the ame, Tab. ead. Fig. 3.

div.head: The Explanation of the Eighth Table.

list.item: C. C. Sternohyoides at Fig. 2. G. G. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 3. ejud. Tab.
L. L. Sternothyroides Fig. 2. at N N. Shews the ame laid bare Fig. 3.
M. M. Hyothyroides Fig. 2. at m. m. Shews the ame bare at Fig. 3. ejud. Tab.
E. E. Styloceratohyoides at Fig. 2. F. F. Shewing the ame laid bare at Fig 3. ejud. Tab.
D. D. Genehyoides at Fig. 2. E. E. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 3. ejud. Tab.
C. Miloglous hews this at Fig. 2.
I. Ceratoglous at Fig. 1. D. Shews this alo at Fig. 2.
F. Crycoarytenoides Anticus at Fig. 1. D. D. Shews the ame laid bare.

div.head: Aeophageus eu Sphincter gulae.
div.p: THe Aeophagus is a round Channel,This contracts the Fauces. by and through which our Nourihment, as both Meat and Drink doth pas from the Mouth into the Stomach, and this Action of Deglutition is performed by the Fibres of the Aeophagus, and its Mucles; for whereas we Eat and Drink at our wills and when our pleaure is this Action is performed when thus made ue of, by uch Intruments as do erve for a voluntary Motion, as Mucles, which are to be numbred with their Animal Actions: and although it may erve for a Natural ue, (as for Nutrition) yet it is no les Animal than Breathing, the which alo is cutomary to Nutrition, yet is it Animal; Now this Sphincter Gulae is very officious in this ervice, for when a due Matication is made,Its e. this by its Contriction doth drive it downwards.

It arieth Flehy, and is a broad Mucle wholly encompaing both the fore and back part of the Aeophagus, ariing laterally according to the length of the Scutiformal Cartilage, encompaing the Aeophagus like a Sphincter; This Mucle being carefully raied, you will much better find Stylopharyngaeus & Cephalopharyngaeus.
D. D. Shews this, Tab. 9. Fig. 5.

div.head: Stylopharyngaeus.
div.p: THis third pair is o called,This dilates and opens the Aeophagus. and do arie with a mall beginning from the inner part of the Styloidal proces, and decending with its thin body, is implanted by a Membranous Tendon into the Thyrois, the ides of the Os Hyoides, and the Root of the Tongue; e. this helpeth forwards the former in its Contraction.
Whereas there are appointed two as Dilators of the Aeophagus, o this is accounted as one of the Contrictors, though Velingius thinks it rather Dilates.
C. C. Shews this, Tab. 9. Fig. 5.

div.head: Cephalopharyngaeus.
div.p: THis arieth from the Cranium, This doth contract the Fauces. and the firt Vertebre of the Neck where they are joyned, and o decending, is implanted into the lateral ides of the Os Hyoides, Cartilago Scutiformis, and the beginning of the Aeophagus, for whom he eems to make a Coat, e. and by lifting this up doth contringe the Fauces in the Deglutition.
A. A. Shews this, Tab. 9. Fig. 5.

div.head: Cricoarytaenoides Poticus.
div.p:
BY Spigelius this is reckoned as one of the firt pair of the Larynx, This extends the Larynx. extending or opening its Cleft, and by Caerius it is called Par Cucullare, it arieth Flehy from the hinder and lower part of the Cricoides, and running up with right Fibres, and repleating the Cavity of the Cricoides, is Nervouly implanted into the inner eat of the Arytaenoides,
e. and by diviion of the Two Arytaenoidal Cartilages, the Larynx is opened. This doth extend the Arytaenois, and by converting it backwards to the outward parts, it opens the Epiglot.
D. D. Shews this at Tab. 9. Fig. 1. G. G. Shews the ame laid bare, Tab. ejud. Fig. 2. C. C. Shews the ame, Fig. 4. ejud. Tab.

list.head: The Explanation of the Ninth Table.
list.item: D. D. Cricoarytenoideus Poticus at Fig. 1. G. G. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 2. D. D. Shews the ame at Fig. 5.
E. E. Cricoarytenoideus Lateralis at Fig. 2. C. C. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 3. C. C. Shews the ame alo at Fig. 6.
F. F. Aritenoides hews this laid bare at Fig. 2.
D. Thyroaritenoides at Fig. 3. B. B. Shews the ame at Fig. 6.

div.head: Cricoarytaenoides Lateralis.
div.p:
THis is generally allowed one of the third pair,This extends it obliquely lateral. extending the Larynx to the ide, or opening its econd Rima or Cleft, it arieth from the lower part of the Annulary Cartilage upwards, and is inerted into the lateral external part of the Arytenoides,
e. opening the Larynx by the oblique diduction of its Cartilages.

Here's alo obervable, That by how much the econd pair of the Contractors doth draw to a mutual Contract, the econd pair of the Extenders do bring them outwards, and o open them. This is generally allowed to extend the Larynx laterally, and o doth open the Rimula.
E. E. Shews thee laid bare, Tab. 9. Fig. 2. C. Shews the ame in itu, Tab. ead. Fig. 3. C. C. Shews them in itu, Tab. ead. Fig. 5.

div.head: Arytaenoides.
div.p: THis is alo called Claudens Secundum, This contracts it obliquely lateral. its very mall and Flehy, and arieth with oblique Fibres from the Arytaenois, where it is joyned to the Cricois, and is again inerted into it, e. where it connecteth its elf with its Companion; This moveth the Arytaenois obliquely, and to either ide, and o by contringing its Bais, doth hut the Glottis

This is called Arytaenoides or Guttalis, and whereas there are allowed two motions of the Larynx, by which it is either contracted or dilated, hut or opened, o doth both thee Dilatations and Contrictions, or Clauion and Apertion proceed from their proper Mucles. Thus when the Thyrois is dilated, the Arytaenoides is hut; and thus according to Galens opinion, the Larynx is contracted when the ides of the Thyrois or Scutiformis are contracted and moved inward, dilated when they are extended and brought outwards, and hut when the Arytaenois is contringed and brought into a cavity, opened when it is brought outwards and extended.

The action of thee Mucles are mot remarkable, when we forcibly top our Breath for ome time, for then it prevails againt the contrary endeavour of the Mucles of the Thorax which erve to Repiration, and huts the Arytaenoides o cloe, that no Air can enter in.
F. F. Shews the ame laid bare, Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. B. B. Shews them at Fig. 4. ejud. Tab.

div.head: Thyreoarytenoides.
div.p: THis is one of the fourth pair,This contracts it • irectly. ariing Flehy, broad, and is tranverely implanted in the Cavity of the Larynx, and from the middle inner part of the Thyrois, and being carried upwards according to its length, is inerted into the lateral part of the Arytaenoidis, which makes the Glottis, the which contringing doth hut the Larynx; This Mucle is bet found by dividing Cartilago Thyroidis, from the Cricoidis, Arytaenoidis, and ubjacent Mucles, the Coats of them being carefully preerved, after which will plainly appear this.
This pair if they be inflamed,Ob. in a Squinancy, when as they do exactly hut the Rima or Cleft, it brings Death along with it.
D. Shews this, Fig. 3. Tab. 9. B. B. Shews the ame at Fig. 6. ejud. Tab.

div.head: Sphenopharyngaeus Primus.
div.p:
THe Mucles of the Fauces,
<…> . by ome the Pharynx or beginning of the Aeophagus, are thoe which do erve for Deglutition, and therefore Nature hath planted at the top of the Aeophagus Mucles here as Intruments of voluntary motion for acting to our wills or pleaures; and as ome of thee do erve for Contriction, o alo are others as ueful for Dilatation, amongt which are thee reckoned as the firt pair.

This arieth thin and Nervous nigh the harp Appendix of the Os Cuneiforme, decending by the inward Cavity of the Pterygoides, and is inerted by a mall Tendon into that Skinny part of the Pallate, from which the Gargareon eems to proceed, and doth dilate thee parts for Reception of their Nutriment.
Neither this nor its fellow are rais'd well or ditinctly without much trouble and d • fficulty.
B. B. Shews this at Tab. 9. Fig. 4.

div.head: Sphenopharyngaeus Secundus.
div.p:
THis econd is by ome allowed to arie from the ame Origination as the former,This helps the former in its dilatation. and is inerted into the lateral and back part of the Fauces and Aeophagus, the which drawing downwards, they do dilate the Cavity of the Fauces and Gula;
e. To find thee after you have raied the Larynx and Aeophagus, leave the Fauces entire, then divide the Fauces themelves from Os Palati, till you come into the Cavity, then carry your Knife cloe internally to the Os Cuneiforme, and being thus divided, you will with eae find both their Originations, and with as much pleaure you may diect them.
This alo is hewn at Tab. 10. Fig. 1. at B. B.

Next to thee hould I have put in the Stomach and Intetines, but Dr. Willis hath given o full an Account of them, and hewn their Fibres o exactly, that whoever deires to take a view of them may be very well atisfied thereof in his Book named Pharmaceutice Rationalis.

div.head: Pterygoides Externus ive Abducens.
div.p: THe lower Mandible hath allowed it variety of Motions,This brings the Mandible forwards. and thee are both very neceary to Human life, as alo for well ordering of their Deigns: for how can the Meat be either received into the Mouth, or there chewed or leened, unles the Mouth were opened, and then hut again; the Teeth do act their parts, and by a mutual Colliion and Comminution towards a fair Deglutition, do make a happy progres towards the health of Man; without the benefit of Mucles, the Grinders mut lie till, and the Inciors grow dull; the Mandible hath its variety of Mucles granted it for the dicharge of its variety of Offices, amongt which this is accounted as one of its fourth pair, and doth arie from the External part of the Proceus Aliformis in part, as alo from the rough and harp Line of the Os Sphaenoidis, trong, Nervous, and Flehy, and o marching down large, is inerted by a trong broad Tendon into the inner part of the lower Mandible, laterally, jut under the Tendon of the Temporal Mucle, and doth move the Mandible forwards, e. and as it were doth abduce it from the Head.
E. E. Shews this at Tab. 10. Fig. 1.

div.head: Pterygoides Internus eu Adducens.
div.p: THis arieth thick and hort from the inner Cavity of the Proceus aliformis, This brings it backwards. being firt Nervous, then Flehy, and is inerted by a broad, long, and Nervous Tendon into the lower Mandible internally lateral, the which drawing it upwards, doth help the Office and Action of Temporalis, bringing the Mandible inwards and backwards. e. Thee two Mucles do not appear until the whole diection of the Tongue, Larynx, and Gula be fully compleated.
D. D. Shews this at Tab. 10. Fig. 1.

div.head: The Explanation of the Tenth Table.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: r. . t. v. Os Ptery. oides.
O. O. Muculus Pterygopalatinus which depreeth the Uvula, and with it the Glandule of the Palate.*
X. X. Shews its Tendon which is reflected about the neck of the Os Pterygoides as on a Trochlea, and is inerted into the Glandule of the Palate.
r. Shews the neck of the Os Pterygoides with its mall head.
a. a. Part of the Mucle Pterygoideus Internus to which is adjacent Pterygopalatinus mentioned at O. O.
C. Shews its Origination ariing from the lower part of the Cavity of the Os Pterygoides.
q. Shews another Mucle called Sphenopalatinus which attols the Glandula Palati, and with that the Uvula. *
f. f. Shews its. Tendon implanted in the ide of the Glandula Palati.
Z. Shews its Origination out of the Os Sphenoides.
g g The Interior Cavities of the Notrils

div.p: Moreover as touching thee two * Mucles (beides what hath already been aid as to their Ues) this Obervation is very material as to their Uefulnes, (viz) in Hauking or forcibly raiing up any tough Flegm or Lapidoue Matter lodged about the Aeophagus, thee are of very great ue as to the dipatch of the ame forward, and ending it outwards, being here planted as two trong Ligaments which can give force to the Pallates raiing it elf for the dicharge of the ame

div.head: Longus.
div.p: THe Neck is as an Appendix to the middle Venter,Th • s contracts the Neck. or a middle between the Head and Trunck. Such Animals are detitute hereof, which do not move their Heads with the Trunck of their Bodies, as Fihes, Frogs, &c. This Neck hath a four fold motion granted it, as forwards, backwards, and to either ide, and every of thee Motions are performed by the benefit of Mucles, of which ome are called Flectors, others Extenors; of the Flectors, the firt pair are called Longi, lying under the Aeophagus.

This Mucle arieth harp and Flehy from the forepart of the Body, from the fifth and ixth Vertebre of the Thorax, where the Rib joyns its elf to him, and o running up under the Aeophagus, is joyned to the ides of the Bodies of all the Vertebres, acending until he comes to the firt of them, where meeting with Scalenus, they inert themelves by a harp Nervous Tendon into the tranvere proces of the firt Vertebre of the Neck.
The Neck by the benefit of thee with the Head, e. is bent or contracted forwards, one only operating, it carrieth it to the ides.
A. A. Shews this, Tab. 10. Fig. 3.

div.head: Scalenus ive Triangularis.
div.p: THee pair of Mucles reembling a Triangular Figure,This contracts the Neck as the former. by ome Anatomits are not improperly called Triangulares.

This arieth from the firt and uppermot Rib of the Thorax, broad and Flehy, and then narrowing himelf, in his upper coure he betows tranvere Fibres upon all the tranvere procees of the Neck, and is inerted as the former, and doth alo help the former forward in their motion; This Mucle hath a peculiar Cavity allowed it, through which the Arteries decending to the Arm, and the Veins acending from thence do pas.
If thee Mucles do work together, e. they do contract and bring the Neck and alo the Head right forwards, but if only one do operate, it inclines the Neck to one ide forwards.
B. Shews that at Tab. 10. Fig. 3.

div.head: Pectoralis.
div.p: THe upper part of the Arm reaching from the top to the Cubile, This m • ves to Arm forwards. is that which we generally do call the Arm, and this is moved by everal Mucles, the firt of which is called either Adducens Humerum, or Pectoralis, by ome the Boxing Mucle, it poeeth the forepart of the Thorax, and arieth firt from the middle of the Clavicle, where he is mot round, and next the Breat Flehy, then from the Sternon according to his length, and is annexed to his Cartilages; Thirdly, from the Cartilages of the ixth, eventh, and eighth Ribs, and is there Nervous in his Origination, and o proceeds Flehy and large until he arrives at the lateral part of the Thorax, where he is converted into a hort, broad, and trong Tendon, and is inerted into Os Humeri, and according to his length between Deltois and Biceps.

This bringeth the Arm to the Breat forwards, e. and hence by ome hath it given it the name of the Boxing Mucle, and this either directly, or omewhat upwards, or downwards, according to the contraction of its upper, middle, or lower Fibres.
B. Shews this in Tab. 16. c. b. d. Shew its divere Fibres.

div.head: Subclavius.
div.p:
THis is called the Subclavius which is eated under the Clavicle, This brings the
<>
upwards and outwards, and doth open the Thorax. and lodgeth between the firt Rib of the Thorax; This is accounted the firt Mucle of the Thorax, it arieth from the Inferior part of the Clavicle, and being enlarged forwards with Oblique and • ranvere Fibres, it is implanted into the firt Rib near the Sternon, and by drawing it upwards and outwards, doth dilate the Thorax.

The ue of this Mucle is for drawing down the Clavicle,
e and Ob. when it is moved upwards with the Scapula, for when the Scapula's are attolled, the Clavicles are lifted up with them, the which to reduce into their proper places, the Subclavius is to be brought downwards; and hence in Fractures of the Clavicles, if they be fractured near the Sternon, the Arm with the Scapula does oon fall downwards, and that part which is next the Sternon doth acend and is raied upwards, as Hippocrates doth oberve, Lib. de Fractur. and on the contrary, if they be broken near the Acromium, you will find neither part to acend: the caue of which, the ame worthy Anthor doth fortifie with this ingenious Reaon; Whereas this Mucle is inerted to that part which is next the Acromium, when the Clavicle is fractured two ways, this Subclavian Mucle is preently contracted; and thus the Arm draws the dependent Scapula together with its elf, whilt the other part is detained in its place by the trength of the Mucle.
F. Shews this, Tab. 11.

div.head: Serratus Major Anticus.
div.p:
THee Mucles of the Scapula have not their Names given them from their Ue,This brings the Scapula forwards. but rather from their Figures, as this pair much reembling the Teeth of a Saw, and hence called Serrati. This is the econd Mucle placed in the ide of the Thorax, ariing from the third, fourth fifth, ixth, eventh, eighth, ninth, aud tenth Ribs, with a Saw-like, Nervous, and harp Origination, hence growing Flehy upon the Ribs, he acends and inerts himelf Flehy into the whole Bais of the Scapula inwards; It is much Diputable both by Spigelius and Velingius,
e. whether the Origination and Inertion be not é contra; the motion of this Mucle is promoted by the Oblique Decendent Mucle of the Abdomen: when this is contracted to its beginning, it draws the Scapula forwards, as alo the Serratus Minor, but omewhat downwards.
And alo as I apprehend, another Ue may be to tie or faten the Scapula to the Breat.
A. Shews this at Tab. 16. a. a. a. Shews its Origination and its Tendon, D. D. Shews the ame at Tab. 11. F. F. F. F. Shews the ame in its place in Tab. 1.

div.head: Serratus Minor Anticus.
div.p: THis is the fourth,This brings it upwards. which wholly lies under the Pectoral Mucle in the fore part of the Thorax, and is called Serratus from its being like a Saw, acuminated with various Flehy Fibres; Minor, as touching its difference with the Major, it is ubtrated to the Pectoral Mucle, ariing from the four firt upper Ribs (but one) by o many errated Originations, and o decending towards the Scapula narrows himelf, and is inerted broad, Flehy, and Nervous into the Proceus rotriformis of it, e. and draweth it forward to the Thorax: if they work both together, they do bring the Scapula to the Breat: if the upper they bring it upwards, and é contra: if the lower, they bring it downwards.
This Mucle hath alo (as I conceive) the ame Ue with the former, binding the Scapula forward to the Trunck of the Body.
E. Shews this laid bare, Tab. 11.

div.head: Intercotales Externi.
div.p:
THee have their Originations from the Tranvere procees of the Back,Thee do dilate the Thorax. where the Ribs are joyned, and o proceeding Flehy, do fix themelves all along from the lowermot part of the upper Rib, external to the upper part of the lower Rib, and o doth proceed to the Cartilage of the Sternon:
e. The outward Mucles being contracted, do draw the Ribs towards their Originations upwards and outwards, in Repiration; hence the Thorax is dilated, and o its Cavity is made wider.

All thee Mucles are endowed with Oblique Fibres,Ob. and thee interecting each other, do hew their differences from the Interni. As a good Obervation to the young Chirurgeon, let him take care in opening of any Abcoes or Empyemas which may happen here, for if he makes a direct Inciion here downwards, he cuts and divides all the Spermatick Fibres, and therefore in thee caes he is advied to make his Inciion in an oblique manner.
K. K. K. K. Shews this at Tab. 11. O. O. O. Shews the ame, Tab. 5.

list.head: The Explanation of the Eleventh Table.
list.item: E. Serratus Minor Anticus hewing it laid bare.
K. K. K. K. Intercotales Externi, Intercotales Interni.

div.head: Intercotales Interni.
div.p: THee have their Originations where the Ribs do begin to bend inwards,Thee do mov • the Thorax and contringe it. and run from the lower to the upper part of the Ribs, not only to the Cartilage, but under that to the Sternon; thee Mucles do work contrary to the former, for thee do bring the Thorax downwards and inwards in Expiration, e. whence it becomes Contrict, and the Cavity is made les.

Moreover, whereas the External Mucles do end about the beginning of the Cartilages, o as that there are left Intercartilaginous paces: hence is it, that Nature, that provident Mitres, who abhors all vacancies, hath filled all thee empty paces with thee Internal Mucles, and hath raied the ame to the Exteriour Superficies of its pace or thoe paces.
Thee you may alo ee with the former.

div.head: Pectoralis Internus eu Triangularis.
div.p:
THis by ome is accounted the ixth Mucle of the Thorax; This doth contringe the Thorax.
it is a mall and thin Mucle ariing from the inner part of the Sternon, and adheres to the Cartilage of the upper Ribs, ending forth on either ide four mall Projections to the Oeal Extremities, by which the third, fourth, fifth, and ixth true Ribs are joyned to the Cartilages, by the adduction of which, e. they do contringe the Thorax, and do omewhat depres it forward.
This Mucle is not to be hewn by any Figure.

div.head: Cremateres ive Supenorii.
div.p: THere are three proper Coats allowed the Teticles,Thee keep the Teticles from falling down. 1t. Erythroides or Tunica rubra, and 2dly. Elytrois, or Vaginalis, and 3dly. Tunica Albuginea, or Nervea: to the External Membrane of the firt are adnated the Cremater Mucles, one on either ide, the which in Men have their Originations from that Ligament which is in the Os Pubis; in Dogs and other Animals they are een to take their Originations from the Tendons of the Tranvere Mucles, and their Flehy Fibres do run through the whole length of the Vaginal Coat, epecially in its back part; for which caue the outward Superfices of this Coat is een to be Aperate and Fibrous, the inward mooth, and covered with a certain waterih Humidity, and is trongly annexed to the lower part of the Teticles.

Regne rus de Graaf doth allow a three fold Ue of this Mucle; e. as firt that it keeps the Teticles from Cold; Then that it keeps them up from falling down, the which by their weight, hould it once o happen, they would hinder the Spermatick Veels in their Operations; And latly, as various Authors have writ and oberved, That they attract them for a better Excretion of the Seed, as is een in the Act of Venery. Bartholinus doth witnes, That there are uch who have this o trong, that they can according to their will retract the Teticles, and then again dimis them.
Tab. 13. Fig. 4. at C. C. you have this, D. D. Shews their Flehy Fibres.

div.head: Erector Penis, ive Collateralis.
div.p: THe Seed made, prepared,This is aid to erect the Penis. and elaborated in the Spermatick Veels do require a proper Intrument for its dicharge into that part which Nature at firt deigned it for, by which means we ee the like produced by the help of this Intrument. Plato in Timaeo did uppoe the Penis to be ome certain Animal, which could produce uch trange effects as touching both Generation and Propagation, but although it is no Animal, yet it mut properly be allowed an Animal-part and Intrument: Its placed in the lower part of the Belly, for the more commodious executing its Office, it takes its Original from a trong Foundation, as from the Bones of the Pubis, to whoe Root it is mot firmly planted; we pas by its Figure and Subtance, and come to its Mucles.
This Mucle has his Original from the Appendix of the Coxendix, beneath the beginning of the two Nervous Bodies, in whoe Interior part their thicket Fibres do terminate and vanih.

Spigelius doth aert that they take their names from their qualities, and that they do erect the Penis, and in coition do preerve the ame; but this is denied by Regnerus de Graaf, as you will ee in the next Chapter: for thee Mucles rather depres the Penis, that o the Seed may be the more traightly ejaculated into the terus.
S. S. Shews this at Tab. 13. Fig. 1. T. T. Shews the ame, Tab. ead. Fig. 2. G. G. Shews this, Tab. 12.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twelfth Table.
Accelerator Penis.
div.p: BEides the former,This aid to dilate the Ur • thra. the Virile Member hath two other Mucles allowed it called Urethram Trahentes, ariing Flehy from the Sphincter Ani, and joyning with its partner internally lateral, and marching by the fore part of the Penis, is inerted into the rethra, and is generally aerted that it was framed for the dilating of the Urethra; but the Ue thus deigned thee Mucles is much rejected by Ren. de Graaf, the which he confuteth by thee Reaons, That when all Mucles do work in their own proper method, their Venters do tumefie, and their ends do approach nearer each other; the which being granted, it cannot thus happen that the Penis hould be extended, the Action of the Mucle being Contraction, and this being mot contrary to Extention; neither can the Penis obtain Erection by the benefit or help of thee Mucles, for it rather would appear depreed than erected thee being contracted, and they being planted in the lower part, or under the Penis, taking their Origination from the Appendix of the Coxendix, and o implanted to the lower part of the Yard.

As to the two alo which are aigned by other Authors to dilate the Urethra, they are in no ways capable to perform this, thee Mucles running through the middle of it, are firmly united to each other by one extremity of Fibres, whilt the oppoite to the former obliquely running over the Urethra, do end the ame into the ides of its Nervous Bodies; but as to the Erection of the Penis two kinds of Veels do eem chiefly to erve with the Mucles for the performance of this, as Nerves and Arteries; but of thee you may plentifully atisfie your elf in Regner. de Graaf, de Organ. Viror. Fol. 154. &c.
This you have at R. R. Tab. 13. Fig. 1. Fig. 2. at S. S. you have the ame, ead. Tab. F. F. Shews the ame, Tab. 12.

div.head: Muculi Clitoridis.
div.p: THe Clitoris hath variety of names betowed on it,This extends the Cli • oris. as Amoris Dulcedo, Oetrum Veneris, Libidinis Sedes, &c. it differs from the Virile Member if you conider its whole Fabrick; Firt, becaue its bifurcated parts are twice longer when joyned, in the Penis when the parts are conjoyned they are four times longer than the bifurcated parts; Then becaue it hath no uch like Channel as hath the Penis, neither is its Glans perforated as is that of the Penis in Men; All Anatomits have by conent allowed that there are Mucles annexed to the Clitoris, but as touching the number of them there is held a Dipute; we judge and allow of two ariing from the Bones of the Coxendix, and running above its Crura, are implanted in them; This Mucle we call Graafiani, and by this the Clitoris is raied.
This Ue we think proper to acribe to the Clitoris and its Mucles,Ob. by the Contraction of the Clitoris and compreing its Thighs, it doth ditend the third Body much more with the Glans.

There is alo another pair of Mucles acribed to the Clitoris by Authors, ariin • from the Sphincterani with a broad beginning, paing by the Lips of the Pudendum, between the Clitoris and Plexus Retiformis, and it is o annexed to the Clitoris, that it is judged that it was appointed rather for the contracting of the Vaginal Orifice, e. than for erecting the Clitoris; and from hence we preume to call it Muculus Labiorum Uteri Contractor.
C. C. Shews thee at Tab. 13. Fig. 4. by this Mucle the Clitoris is depreed, D. D. Shews its Flehy Fibres, E. E. The Flehy Fibres of the Sphincter annexed to the Nervous ubtance of the Clitoris.

div.head: Levatores Ani.
div.p: THat part we generally call the Anus is that which is the end of the Intetinum Rectum; This lifts it up. thee arie from the Ligaments of the Coxendix, and Os Sacrum, under the Bladder, mall, thin, broad, and Membranous, and are inerted into each ide of the Podex; Thee Mucles being very much relaxed, e. do uffer a Procidentia Ani, or rather Prolapus Intetini, thee are bet dicovered before you remove the Intetinum Rectum, Veica, and adjacent parts.
R. R. Shews thee at Tab. 13. Fig. 2. K. K. Shews the ame, Tab. 12.

div.head: Sphincter Ani.
div.p: THis from its Ue is called Contrictor Ani, This pures up the Anus. or Orbicularis, it arieth from the lower Vertebres of the Os Sacrum, round, and broad, joyning himelf largely circular to the Intetinum Rectum with Tranvere Fibres much thicker above than below, where he adheres o firmly to the Cutis, that it is carce eparable: and hence by ome Anatomits it is called Cuticulous.

We acknowledge the Ue and Nobility of either of thee, e. for when they any wie uffer a Paralyis, this being hurt, the Excrements involuntarily do come down, and for the ervice they do in this cae, they are called Contrictores
Q. Shews this at Tab. 13. Fig. 2. I. Shews the ame, Tab. 12.

div.head: Sphincter Veicae.
div.p: THe Urinary Bladder is an Organick Membranous part of the lower Belly,This pures the Bladder. the which is formed as a receiver to take the Urine into it, or Serum which paeth from the Kidneys into it, and at due time doth alo erve for a dicharge of the ame, and o this Bladder hath two Mucles given it, the one is aid to retain the Urine in it, the other drives it out; How unkind would Human life be, if it hould be continually attended with a continual dropping of Urine, as alo how troubleome would it be to Mankind to be perplexed with as great a toppage; therefore kind Nature as he hath been o free as to give the Bladder one pair to keep it in whilt it is convenient to dicharge it, o alo hath he been as provident to let it out when the Bounds of Nature commands a dicharge thereof: the firt from its Office hath gained the name of Sphincter.

This is placed orbicularly in the neck of the Bladder, carcely ditinct from the ubtance of it, only where you find a round Induration, this is the ame, this doth keep the Urine from involuntary falling out from the Bladder, puring it up.
O. O. Shews this at Tab. 13. Fig. 1.

div.head: Detruor Urinae.
div.p: THis is aid to arie betwen the common,This lets is out. and econd proper Coat of the Bladder, the firt Coat properly being his, if not him, and therefore it is very Fabulous, which ome Phyitians o trongly contend for, that beides the former they will allow the Bladder many other Mucles, but in truth the bet of Authority doth not afford any other of the Bladder beides thee two already named.

This Mucle therefore is only the middle Coat of the Bladder, which coniting of Carnous Fibres running length-ways erves to the expulion of the Urine. The tone of thee Fibres is much injured when the Bladder is overmuch ditended with Urine, or when it is held too long.
M. M. M. Shews this, Tab. 13. Fig. 1.

list.head: The Explanation of the Thirteenth Table.
list.item: S. S. Erector Penis at Fig. 1.
T. T. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 2.
R. R. Accelerator Penis at Fig. 1.
S. S. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 2.
C. C. Muculi Clitoridis at Fig. 4. and at D. D. E. E.
R. R. Levatores Ani at Fig. 2.
M. M. M. Detruor Urinae at Fig. 1.

div.head: Diaphragma.
div.p: THis Mucle hath its Origination from the firt Vertebre of the Loins;This ditinguihes the lower Be • ly from the middle. obtaining a circular Figure, and much different in itu from other Mucles, anwering in magnitude the tranvere bottom of the Thorax, and is inerted into the forepart of the Sternon, and Termination of the True Ribs, and to the twelfth Rib, as alo to the extremities of the batard Ribs, on the Sides.

It is in its middle (for its greater trength) Membranous and Nervous,Ob. to which middle the Flehy Fibres do run as to their Center: Wounds happening in this Center, are reputed Mortal, becaue hence uddainly doth follow a preent decay of Repiration, and very troubleome Convulions, whereas Wounds happening in the Flehy parts hereof, are void of this danger allowed by Galen, and this is confirmed by various examples.

The Diaphragma borrows its Origine from the Vertebres of the Back near the Loins, e. and round the Termination of the Ribs and Eniformis Cartilago, and hath its Tendon in its Center or middle of it: and by contracting it elf, moveth downward, bringing it elf from an Arch toward a Plain, and o enlargeth the Cavity of the Thorax to give way to the blown up Lungs, inpired with numerous Particles of Air.

Next to this hould I have Dicoured of the Heart, that Royal Mucle of the Body, by the Reciprocal motion of whoe Fibres all that Blood is let both into it and out of it, by which our Human Pile is kept up and preerved: but Doctor Lower having already o fully written hereof, and alo given uch exact Figures of all its variety of Fibres, I recommend the Reader wholly to his Book De Corde, my task more properly relating to thoe of the Artus.
This you have at Tab. 16. Fig. 2.

div.head: Here let the Body be turned upon its Face.
Cucullaris ive Trapezius.
div.p: THis is the firt,This moves the Scapula variouly. the which with its Companion doth very aptly expres a Monks Hood: it takes its Origination Flehy from the lower part of the Os Occipitis, and from the Spines of the Vertebres of the Neck, and the eight upper Spines of the Thorax, and pringeth Membranous, broad, and running externally towards the Scapula, grows narrower, and is inerted into the whole Spine of the Scapula, and near half his Bais, as alo to part of the Clavicle, by a broad, Nervous, and Flehy Origination, and by the variety of Fibres allowed it, e. it is variouly moved, as upwards, downwards, directly, obliquely, according as its Fibres are variouly contracted; Divide this Mucle from its partner at their Originations from the Spines of the Vertebres, and being o followed and cleared from the Os Occipitis, the Mucles underneath this will much better appear.
And I conceive another Ue of this Mucle may be to faten the Scapula to the Vertebres of the Neck and Thorax; but the chief Ue of it is to move the Scapula obliquely upwards.
This you have at A. A. A. B. Tab. 14. B. Shews its Tendinous Inertion into the Scapula, a. b. c. Its three orts of Fibres.

div.head: The Explanation of the Fourteenth Table.

list.item: B. B. Shews one part thereof laid bare.
G. G. G. G. Latiimus Dori.

div.head: Latisimus Dori, ive Anicalptor.
div.p:
THis Abducent Mucle,This brings the arm backwards to the Fundament. or Latiimus is o called from its magnitude, the which with its Companion doth near cover the Back, it arieth with a large Membranous beginning from the Spines of the Vertebres of the
• horax, between the Os Sacrum, and the ixth Vertebre of the Thorax, as alo from the upper part of the Os Ileon: his Origination here is chiefly Membranous, but running higher, o oon as it attains the curvation of the Ribs, he grows Flehy, and in his acenion becoming narrower, is carried over the lower Angle of the Scapula, and by a trong and hort, but broad Tendon, he is implanted below the upper head of Os Humeri, between the Pectoralis and Rotundus, great care mut be had, let in the raiing this Mucle from his Origination, you do take up the Origination of the ubjacent Mucle Serratus Major Poticus, and if you be not very careful in your diection, you will borrow from Quadratus Lumbi, as you raie him from the Ileon, to which he firmly adheres; e. as alo near the Scapula, Serratus Major Anticus will arie with him, without mature and deliberate obervation hereof: this brings the Arm backwards, ometimes upwards; its diverity of Fibres contracting themelves doth occaion thee variety of Motions.
This is hewn at Tab. 14. at G. G. D. C. C. Shews its Origination, D. Shews where its Tendon arieth, N. N. O. O. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 15.

div.head: Rhomboides.
div.p:
THis is o called from Rhombus, This brings the Scapula backwards. the which is by Mathematicians aid to be a fourquare Figure, not coniting of equal Angles, but of Lines: it arieth broad and Flehy immediately under the Cucullaris, from the Spinal procees of the three lower Vertebres of the Neck, and three upper Vertebres of the Thorax, whence running with thin Fibres, it decends down to the Scapula, to whoe whole Bais externally, it adheres broad and Flehy; in the raiing of this, take care that you do not raie the Tendon of Serratus Poticus Superior,
e. who lies jut under him. And alo becaue it taketh its Origine from the three lower Vertebres of the Neck, and the three upper of the Thorax, and is inerted into the Bais of the Scapula, whereupon it doth ait the Cucullaris, and bind the Scapula backward to the lower part of the Neck and upper part of the Thorax.

This Mucle holds the Scapula to the Back: hence Conumptive people have prominent Scapula's from the weaknes of this Mucle; from this alo in ome Perons may an account be given of the Gibboity of this part.
This you have at Tab. 15. at B. B. in itu, c. c. c. c. Shews its Origination, G. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 24. h. h. i. Shews its beginning and ending.

div.head: Levator Patientiae.
div.p:
THis is alo called Scapulam Attollens: This brings it forwards. This arieth from the econd, third, fourth, and fifth Tranvere Procees of the Neck, and hath as many Originations with their Intertitia: thee joyning do decend, and adjoyn to the whole upper ide of the Rhomboides, until it is inerted by a broad, Flehy Tendon to the highet, as alo to the lower Angle of the Scapula,
e. and doth draw the ame upwards and forwards, and is raied with the Arm.
This Mucle had its name from Spigelius: it bearing many heavy burdens, for the Scapula by the help hereof with the Arm is lifted up forwards, and hence takes the better name of Patientiae.
This you have at Tab. 15. at A. laid bare, 1. 2. 3. 4. Shews its four beginnings.

div.head: Rotundus Major.
div.p: THis is alo called Humerum Deprimens, This draws the Arm down backwards. its alo called Rotundus, it being Sphaerical; it arieth with a Flehy beginning from the lower Angle of the Scapula, and adheres Flehy from his lower Rib, and having marched half way, deerts, and being indifferently dilated omewhat upwards, is inerted by a hort, broad, and trong Tendon into that part of the Os Humeri where Pectoralis hath his inertion, and doth draw the Arm down backwards. e. It partly lies under the Arm-pit.

Its generally oberved by all Maters of Anatomy,Ob. that all Depreers are much les then the Attollers in Human Body. Thus the Temporalis is the tronget Attollent of the lower Mandible, and Biventer is the mot infirm Depriment, and the reaon is, there is required much more for the lifting up of a weight, than for his bringing down.
This you have at Tab. 15. at E.

div.head: Supercapularis Superior ive Suprapinatus.
div.p:
THis is Flehy and long,This brings it about outwards. and preeth the whole Scapula upwards: it arieth from the whole Bais of the Scapula Flehy above the Spine, filling the whole Cavity between the Spine and the upper Rib of the Scapula, and going back to the neck of it, paeth under the econd Ligament of the Humerus, as the Biceps doth, and is inerted by a broad and trong Tendon obliquely into the neck of the Os Humeri,
e. and doth bring the Arm about with the former; others do affirm that it moves the Arm upwards with the Deltois. And I apprehend that a great Ue of this Mucle is to help the Coracobrachialis and Infrapinatus, in lifting up the Arm.
This you have at Tab. 15. at F. L. Shews the ame laid bare.

div.head: Supercapularis Inferior ive Infrapinatus.
div.p: THis covereth the whole Exteriour part of the Scapula, This brings the Arm about outwards. which under the Spine, ariing from almot the whole Bais of the lower part of the Scapula, and poeing the major part of that Cavity, Flehy, running backward, narrows himelf according to the form of the part, e. and by a broad Tendon is inerted into the Ligament of the Os Humeri, as ome will have it; But I humbly conceive, That this Mucle according to its ituation, doth more probably ait the Deltoeides and Coracobrachialis, lifting the Os Humeri upward.
This you have at Tab. 15. at G. M. Shews the ame laid bare.

div.head: Nonus Humeri Placentini ive Rotundus Minor.
div.p: FAllopius calls this Tranveralis Brevior from its ite, This helps the motion of Rotundus Major. and Rotundus from its form: It arieth harp and Flehy from the lowet Angle of the Scapula, at his Bais, and growing more Flehy to its Venter, decreaes again, and terminates himelf by a harp Tendon into the neck of Os Humeri; This by ome Anatomits is held as a part of that Mucle called Rotundus Major.

This Mucle depreeth the Os Humeri,
e. and is an Antagonit to the Deltoeides and Coracobrachialis.

This you have at Tab. 17. at Fig. 2. at A. B. C. A. Shewing its Flehy beginning, B. Its Cavity or Fiure, C. Its thin and Nervous Tendon; This you have alo at Fig. 1. Tab. id. at P. P. Q. Q. Q. Shews the Nerve that paes through this into other Mucles.

div.head: Subcapularis.
div.p: THis is eated in the Cavity of the Scapula, This brings the Arm inwards. and poeeth the whole Cavity thereof: it arieth Flehy from the whole inward Bais of the Scapula, and o running forwards, according to the dimenions of the Bone, narrowing himelf, and by a broad Tendon, is inerted into the third Ligament of the Os Humeri.

Thee lat Mucles do work the whole Arm about, e. from whence they have alo their names, but the Subcapularis brings it inwards, the Supercapularis Inferior outwards, and alo upwards, but thee together do moderately elevate it; their Ue may be mot commodiouly hewn, if the whoe Arm be put into a middle Figure, and afterwards, neither abduces from the Breat to the Arm, neither the middle Figure changed with the Cubite of the Arm, the Cubitus being drawn outwards, and again brought inwards.
This you have at Tab. 11. at C. C.

list.head: The Explanation of the Fifteenth Table.
list.item: C. C. C. C. Shews the Spines of the Vertebres, from whence they do take their Origination.

div.head: The Explanation of the Sixteenth Table.

list.item: ae. ae. ae. Shews its Originations.
B. Pectoralis. c. b. d. Shews its diverity of Fibres.
F. F. F. F. Deltois. H. H. I. Shews it laid bare.
K. Shews the ame omewhat laid bare.

div.head: If the whole Arm with the Scapula be taken off, the diection of thee following Mucles will with more eae be performed.
Deltois.
div.p:
THis is accounted the econd Mucle of the Arm,This lifts up the Arm. called by ome Triangularis Humeralis, ariing generally Nervous; Firt, forward from the middle of the Clavicle where it is broadet, next the Os Humeri; Secondly, from the top of the Scapula, where it is joyned to the Clavicle; Thirdly, from the whole Spine of the Scapula, thee Originations preently growing Flehy, decending and narrowing become a trong Tendon, externally Flehy, internally Nervous, which is tranverely planted under the neck of Os Humeri;
e. this lifts up the Arm ometimes directly, ometimes forwards, or backwards according to its Series of Fibres, thee being contracted: In the middle part hereof unexperienced Chirurgeons do make Fontanels, Ca • tion. but very inconiderately, becaue this Mucle being contracted, the Orifice of the Fontanel therein made is alo therewith contracted, ending thereby the Pea forth with force and pain, and the Iue doth heal up preently; which Errour may with eae be hunned, if they made them in the ditance between this and the Biceps, four or five Fingers breadth from the joynt of the Arm, in which place, when the Arm is bent, there is preently perceived this Intertitium.
This you have at F. F. Tab. 16. H. H. I. Shews the ame laid bare.

div.head: Biceps.
div.p: THis Mucle arieth with a double beginning,This Mucle bends the • ulit • . ariing fi • t externally from the top of the Acetabulum Scapulae by one Subtance, and o runs under the Ligament of that Juncture over the head of the Os Humeri, and through a Channel inculpt for it, where it is bound in by a proper Ligament; Secondly, ariing broad, Flehy, and Nervons from the Coracoidal Apophyis of the Scapula, and is carried over the internal head of the Os Humeri, and o decending meets with the other, and makes one trong and Flehy Mucle, and narrowing himelf becomes a trong, thick, large, and Nervous Tendon, and is inerted into an Oblong Prominence under the upper head of the Radius.

Its this Tendon which generally doth lie under the middle Vein of the Arm,Caution. which cautioneth all young Chirurgeons to beware of it in Venae Sectione, for it produceth great danger to the Patient: for Wounds received here are of very great Conequence, becaue both Veins, Nerves, and Arteries are very relative to it and bordering upon it, the which, of what direful conequence it hath been many Maters of our Art in this Honourable City can both evince and certifie.
This Biceps bendeth and lifteth up the Cubite. e.
This you have at Tab. 16. at L. M. And at Tab. 17. at G. H. I. you have the ame, G. Shewing its firt head, H. Another head of this Mucle, I. Shewing its Flehy belly, K. Its thick and Nervous Tendon.

div.head: Octavus Humeri Placentini, ive Perforatus eu Coracobrachialis.
div.p: THis arieth by a hort and Nervous Origination from the Coracoidal proces of the Scapula, This draws the Arm upward. near the Origination of the Deltois, and o decending, becomes omewhat long, large, and Flehy, and is implanted by a trong Tendon into the middle of the Os Humeri, and doth adduce it with the Pectoralis forwards to the Breat, e. as ome would have it; the Venter hereof is perforated, and through the body of this Mucle doth pas a Nerve, which erves the ret of the Mucles; Riolan. reckoned this Mucle to be a part of the Biceps, or of the firt Mucle of the Cubite, which doth contradict Autopy.
And I do humbly conceive that this Mucle in truth doth ait the Deltoides in bending the Arm, and lifting up the Os Humeri.
This you have at Tab. 15. at a. in its place, b. Shewing the ame laid bare.

div.head: Brachiaeus Internus.
div.p:
THis Mucle lodgeth under Biceps, This bends the Cubite forwards. but is more hort and Flehy: it arieth about the middle of the Os Humeri, near the inertion of the Deltois, and Pectoralis double, broad, and Flehy: partly by the Exteriour, partly by the inner ide of the aid Bone, but preently joyning, and firmly adhering to the Bone, in its decent becoming large till at lat it terminates broad and Flehy in the Ligament of the Joynt, as well as in the Appendices of the Cubite and Radius;
e. This with the Biceps doth very trongly contract the Cubite, lifting it up, being an aitant to the Biceps
This you have at M. N. O. at Tab. 17. M. Shewing its beginning, N. Its Venter or Belly, O. Its large and Flehy Tendon.

div.head: The Explanation of the Seventeenth Table.

list.item: R. R. S. S. Gemellus Major.
Gemellus Minor you have alo in the ame Table.

div.head: Gemellus Major, Brachiaeus Externus, aut Longus.
div.p: THis Mucle arieth doubly broad and trong,This extends the Cubite. partly Flehy, partly Nervous, from the lower part of the Scapula, where it hath a peculiar Cavity a little under the neck of it: and growing Flehy decends, and joyns himelf to the inner ide of the Os Humeri, where he meets with his other Flehy Origination, and o making one, is carried down to the inner ide of the Proces of the Olecranum, and is there implanted; The Ue of this Mucle is generally reputed to extend the Cubite, e. and is an Antagonit Mucle to the Biceps Internus, which is a Flexor and lifter up of the Cubite: and the Biceps Externus doth extend it, and put it backward and depres it.
This and its following partner you have decribed at R. R. S. S. Tab. 17. R. R. Shewing its beginnings, S. S. Its double Venter.

div.head: Extenor Cubiti Breuis, vel Brachiaeus Internus.
div.p: THis is the econd of the Extenders of the Cubite,This doth ait the former in its extention. and doth arie backwards Nervous from the neck of the Os Humeri, and o becoming Flehy, decends to the middle of Os Humeri, and doth ineparably mix himelf with the former, and at length is inerted partly Flehy, partly Nervous into the outward ide of the Olecranum, about the place we lean on. Thee two Mucles as they have right Fibres given them from their beginning to their ends, e. they do extend the Cubite directly, as the two former did contract it.

p.U: ays this Mucle aries from the middle of the Os Humeri, and it is accordingly repreented o in his Cuts.

div.p: This and its partner you have hewn at R. R. S. S. at Tab. 17.

div.head: Anconaeus.
div.p: THis being but a mall bodied Mucle,This doth alo extend the Cubite. doth arie from the lower and back part of the Os Humeri, being planted between the Cubitus and the Radius, and is inerted with a Nervous Tendon (ometimes obliquely) into the lateral part of the Ul • a, a Thumbs length below the Olecranum or Elbow; e. As thoe two lat do help forward the Cubites extention, this doth help the former, &c.
This is not to be hewn or repreented by Figure.

div.head: Palmaris.
div.p: THis arieth round and Nervous,This moves the Palm of the Hand. from the inward Extuberance of Os Humeri, and preently becoming Flehy and narrow, about the middle of the Cubite is carried omewhat obliquely, and is turned into a long and round Tendon, and paing over the inward Ligament of the Radius comes to the Palm and there doth expand it elf into a mot broad Tendon, and is laterally inerted into the firt Joynts of the Fingers, and is o cloely fixed to the Cutis, that it is not thence to be eparated without difficulty; e. The contraction of this Cutis occaioneth apprehenion, and doth endue the Palm of the Hand with an Exquiite Sene, and the Skin becoming immovable by the gripe, it occaioneth a more teady keeping of any thing therein contained.

The learned Fallopius hath oberved this Mucle ometimes to be double in either Arm,Ob. and ariing from the ame place, that one doth end in a broad Tendon, uch as already is decribed, the other, in the Tranvere Ligament of the Carpus.

This you have at Tab. 18. Fig. 1. at D. E. Shews where it paeth into a Tendon, b. Shews the expanion of the ame Tendon, G. G. G. G. Its Terminations; At the ame Letter you have the ame expreed at the econd Figure Tab. ejud.

div.head: Caro Muculoa Quadrata.
div.p: NEar adjacent to the former,This doth ait the former. is planted a Flehy Subtance ariing from the Membrana Carnoa under Mons Lunae, where the eighth Bone of the Carpus is placed, and then marcheth under Palmaris, to the middle of the Palm, and is inerted into the outide of that Tendon that eparates the little Finger from the ret; e. this makes the Hand hollow, and the Ue hereof is perceived and declared in large contractions of the Palm, drawing the Mons Lunae to the middle of the Hand: this is when we would make it appear very hollow.
This you have at P. P. at Fig. 2. Tab. 18.

div.head: Flexor Carpi Interior ive Ulnaris.
div.p: THis arieth harp,This bends the Writ. Flehy and Nervous from the inner Apophyis of the Os Humeri, and o running Flehy the whole length of the Cubite, to which it adheres, hath its Inertion at the Writ into its fourth Bone, partly Nervous, partly Flehy, this paeth not under the Tranvere Ligament, but is only wrapt up with the common Membrane of all the Mucles; e. Its Ue is thus, uch as are the Inflectors do poes the whole part, and do arie from the inward Protuberance of the Arm: thoe that do extend, do arie from the back part and outward Extuberance.

This you have at Tab. 18. at Fig. 1. at R. R. f. Shewing its Flehy and Nervous beginning, g. Its end partly Flehy, partly Nervous; This alo you have at the econd Figure at the ame Table, at the ame Letter: K. K. Shews the ame in itu at Tab. 19. at Fig. 1. b. Shewing its beginning, c. d. Its end as formerly.

div.head: Flexor Carpi Exterior ive Radialis.
div.p: THis arieth as the former from the ame Extuberance,This doth help the former in its Contraction. and o running omewhat tranverly near the outer part of the Primi Digitorum Flexores, is fixed to the Radius, and a little before it arrives at the Carpus doth become a round Tendon, which cleaving to the Tranvere Ligament, runneth under him, and enlarging himelf, is inerted into that Os Metacarpi which tands before the little Finger; thee two do contract the Hand.
Thee two working together, e. the Carpus, and the Hand with it is alo contracted; one only working, its ometimes moved into that ide omewhat obliquely which is contracted.

This you have at Tab. 18. Fig. 1. & 2. at S. S. in itu, L. Shewing its beginning, M. Its lender and Nervous Termination, L. L. Shews the ame at Tab. 19. in itu, e. Shews there its Flehy beginning, f. The Tendon of this Mucle, G. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 20. Fig. 1.

div.head: Flexor Secundi Internodii Perforatus.
div.p: THe Fingers,This contra is the econd Joynt of the Fingers. which are the great Meengers of Writing our Minds, and which are implanted in us for performing of many trong and vigorous Motions, do act thee by the benefit of Mucles, by which they are both contracted, extended, and brought to a lateral Ue; We begin with the Contractors, thee being eated in the Cubite, and thoe generally do gain the name of Contractors which do bring the four Fingers into a Curvation; Of thee Mucles of the Fingers, this is aid to be the firt, and taketh its name from its Ue, e. contracting the econd Bone of the Fingers.

It arieth from the inward Protuberance of Os Humeri, under the former, and o growing broad and Flehy about the middle of the Cubitus and Radius, omewhat adhereing thereto marcheth forwards, and becomes wholly round and Flehy near the Writ, where it is divided into four Flehy Portions, from which proceeds o many Tendons, all which are involved in one proper Mucaginous and thin Coat, and o running internally under the Ligament, gets through the Palm, and then doth ditribute to the firt and econd Joynts of the four Fingers, as many Tendons which are perforated a little before their inertion for the tranmiion of the Tendons of Tertii Internodii Flexor This Mucle by ome is called Sublimis & Perforatus.
This you have at Q. Q. Tab. 18. at both Figures in itu, d. Shews its Origination, e. e. Its Bivaricated Tendon, D. D. D. D. Shews the ame at Tab. 19. Fig. 1. C. C. C. C. Shews it laid bare at Fig. 2.

list.head: The Explanation of the Eighteenth Table.
list.item: D Palmaris at Fig. 1. E. Shews where it paeth into a Tendon.
F. Declares where it expands it elf into a broad Tendon.
G G. G. G. Shews the Termination of thee Tendons.
O. O. O. O. Flectentes Pollicem.
Q. Q. Flexor Secundi Internodii Digitorum.
d. Shewing its beginning at Fig. 2. e. e. Its Bivaricated Tendons.
R. R. Flexor Carpi Interior, f. g. Shews its Origination and Termination.
S. S. Flexor Carpi Exterior, L. M. Shews its Origination and Termination
Y. Y. Tertium Pollicis Internodii Flectens.
Z. Z. Pars quaedam Flexoris Tertii Internodii Digitorum.

div.head: Flexor Tertii Internodii.
div.p: THis doth contract the third Joynt,This contracts the third Joynt of the Finger. and from thence doth takes its name: by ome it is called Profundus, as alo Perforans; it arieth Membranous ome part of him, from the ame Extuberance as the former, the ret from the Root of the forward proces of the Olecranum, becoming afterwards exactly round and Flehy, running under the former, and adhering inwards to the Cubitaeus, on the outward to the Primi pollicis Flexor, and decending about the middle of the Cubite, they divide, and make their progres through the Fiures of the others, and are inerted into the third Joynts of the Fingers: and that a right inflection may be made by thee Mucles, and that the contracted Tendons may not rie up, and o lift up the Cutis in the inward part of the hand according to their length, a Channel being made out of the hard Membranes, they are inwardly included with a fatty and Oleaginous Humour in which they have their free coure of Motion.
Thee Mucles are allowed to contract the third Joynts of the Fingers. e.
This you have at Tab. 18. at Z. Fig. 1. & 2. This you have exactly at Tab. 19. Fig. 2. at D. D. a. a. a. a. Shewing its four Tendons.

div.head: Flexor Secundi Internodii Pollicis.
div.p: THis Flexor is not eated in the Hand,This bends the econd Joynt of the Thumb. as the former, but in the Flehy part of the Cubite: it arieth round and Flehy from the Os Cubiti, and o marching along by the Radius to which it adheres, as alo to the Membrane that joyns the Cubitus and Radius, it comes to the Writ, where it becomes a round Nervous Tendon, having alo a proper thin Mucaginous Membrane, and o marching forwards, is inerted into the econd joynt of the Thumb by a omewhat broad Tendon.
This contracts the econd Joynt of the Thumb, e. to which it is fixed.
This you have at Y. Y. Tab. 18. Fig. 1. This alo you have at P. P. Fig. 1. Tab. 19. This you have laid bare at Tab. 20. at M. M.

div.head: Pronator Radii Teres.
div.p: THe Radius is wrought with two Motions,This brings the Writ downwards. the one per accidens, the other per e, and hence hath it given it two kinds of Mucles: the firt from their Ues are called Pronatores, the other Supinatores. The econd of the Pronators is called Teres, o called from its form, it arieth from the Root of the inner prominence of the Os Humeri, and from the inide of the Os Cubi • i, and is there joyned by a large Flehy Origination to the Radius, and thence decending obliquely downwards by his inner ide a little above the middle, is implanted into him Flehy, from whence a Nervous Head doth proceed, which is inerted into the External Head of the Radius.
This Mucle is held to bring the Radius downwards. e.

This you have at X. in both Figures Tab. 18. n. Shewing its Origination; This alo you have at Tab. 19. Fi • . 1. At O G. Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. you have the ame at K. d. Shewing its Origination, e. Its Termination, C. C. Shews the ame at Tab. 20. Fig. 1. a. Demontrating its beginning, b. Its Termination.

div.head: Pronator Quadratus ive Inferior.
div.p: THis is allowed the firt of the Pronators, This works as the former. it is wholly Flehy, and arieth from the lower and inner part of the Cubite near the Radius, running over the Ligament that joyns the Cubite and the Radius tranverly, and o doth implant himelf Flehy into the inward part of the Radius, with a broad beginning, much repreenting a Mathematical Square, having four equal ides.
Thee two Mucles, e. while they are contracted towards their Originations, do move the Radius forwards, and o doth connect the Hand which the lower part of the Radius by the benefit of the Carpus.
This you have at Tab. 19. Fig. 1. at I. K. Shews this, Tab. 20. Fig. 1. e. e. Shews its beginning, f. f. Its Termination.

div.head: The Explanation of the Nineteenth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: D. D. D. D. Flexor Secundi Internodii Digitorum. E. E.
E. E. Shews its four Tendons.
F. F. F. F. Lumbricales. G. G. G. G. Shews thee four Tendons.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: C. C. C. Flexor Secundi Internodii Digitorum laid bare.
D. D. Flexor Tertii Internodii. a. a. a. a. Shews its four Tendons.
F. F. F. F. Lumbricales, b. b. b. b. Shews their Originations.
G. G. Flexor Tertii Internodii Pollicis laid bare. c. Shews its Tendon.
K. Secundus Radii Teres. d. Shews its Origination.
O. Primus Secundi Pollicis Articuli Flexor.
P. Flexor Primus Primi Pollicis Internodii.

div.head: Flexores Primi Internodii ive Lumbricales.
div.p: THee are mall and lender Mucles,Thee bend the Fingers laterally. ariing round, long, and lender, from thoe Membranes which do enwrap the Tendons of Tertii Internodii Flexores, and o paing on Flehy, are inerted by a round, Nervous Tendon into the firt of the Joynts of the Fingers, and are bet hewn by raiing one from his Origination, and leaving him in his Inertion, e. and the other é contrario, thee bends the Fingers laterally.

This you have at F. F. F. F. Tab 19. Fig. 1. G. G. G. G. Shews their four Tendons, F. F. F. F. Shews the ame at the ame Tab. Fig. 2. b. b. b. b. Shewing their Originations, F. F. F. F. Shews the ame in its place, Fig. 21. Tab. 21. f. f. f. f. The beginning of thee Mucles, g. g. g. g. Shews their Tendons.

div.head: Flexor Primus, Primi Internodii Pollicis.
div.p: THe Thumb is bent or contracted in its Joynts,This bends the Thumb. and thee after everal ways, and hence have they their names everally betowed upon them, ome of thee being Contractors of the firt, others of the econd.

This firt arieth Flehy from the upper eat of the Annulary Ligament which is in the Carpus, near the Thumb, and acending, doth encompas the firt and econd Joynts of the Thumb, and is inerted into the head of the firt Joynt Flehy.
This you have at Tab. 19. Fig. 1. at P. P. This you have alo at A. B. Tab. 21. Fig. 1. This you have alo at the econd Fig. ejud. Tab. at B.

div.head: Secundus.
div.p: THis being maller then the former,This helps the former in its contraction. arieth Flehy, partly from the ame Ligament, and partly from Os Carpi, next the Thumb, and running under the other, is implanted into the ame Joynt from its Root, even to its middle: this is wholly lodged under the former, and is covered over with its breadth.

Thee two do bend the Joynt of the Thumb, e. and adduceth it to the Hand. Riolanus doth not acknowledge this as a Flexor, but rather doth think, that the Mucles ariing from the Bones of the Carpus, and Metacarpus, to be either Adductors or Abductors.
This you have at Tab. 19. at M. M. Fig. 1.

div.head: Secundi Internodii Pollicis, Flexor Primus.
div.p: THis Mucle arieth broad,This bends the econd Joynt of the Thumb. thin, and Flehy, from that Os Metacarpi that receiveth the Fore-finger a little below his head, and running towards his Thumb grows omewhat triangular, and is inerted by a Membranous Tendon into the head of the econd Joynt of the Thumb on the ide next the Fore-finger.
This Mucle by mot Anatomits is allowed to bend the econd Joynt of the Thumb. e.
This you have at O. O. O. O. Fig. 1. & 2. Tab. 18. C. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 21. Fig. 2. This is alo hewn in itu at Tab. 18. at i. Fig. both.

div.head: Secundus.
div.p: THis arieth with a broad and Flehy beginning,This worke as the former. from the middle part of Os Metacarpi of the third Finger, running to the Thumb, and is inerted into the middle of the econd Joynt thereof, in its inward part.

This Mucle is aid to be next to the former, and thus each do ucceed one another in place and order; and as touching their proper Ues, you will meet them all ummed up together in Quarto Muculorum Digitorum.
This you have at Tab. 18. at O. O. I.

div.head: Tertius.
div.p: THis follows the econd,This doth operate as the former. and is contiguous to it, this arieth broad and Flehy from the Os Metacarpi of the the third Finger, and is implanted into the ame with the former.

This Mucle is alo allowed to begin where the other ended: all thee together do make up that Flehy Mas which our Chiromancers make ue of, which you have more fully in the next; they are contracted according to the Bone moving towards the other Fingers, and according to their variety of Operations they do expres their diverity of Ues.
This you have at O. 3. in Tab. 18. at both Figures; This you have laid bare at D. D. Tab. 21. Fig. 2.

div.head: Quartus.
div.p: THis arieth Flehy from the Os Metacarpi of the Little Finger about the middle of it,This brings the Thumb to the Little Finger. and running under the other, is inerted into the ame Joynt as the former.

All thee Mucles are Flehy, of which, the two contracting the firt Joynt, with that abducing the Thumb, do contitute that little Hillock of the Thumb o called by Chiromancers; but the third of the econd Joynt maketh whatoever is Flehy between the Life-Line, and the aforeaid little Hill; thee are contracted according as the ret of the Joynts of the Fingers, e. and they working together, do bring the Thumb to the ide of the Little Finger, hereby working the Hand into a hollownes.
This Mucle brings the Thumb up to the great or Fore-Finger.
This Mucle running under the former is not to be hewn by Figure.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twentieth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: a. Shews its beginning, b. Its Termination.
D. D. Carpi Flexor & Extenor Internus laid bare.
G. Externus Carpi Flexor laid bare.
M. M. Secundi Pollicis Internodii Flexores laid bare.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: b. b. b. Its threefold diviion, f. f. f. Shews three Tendons belonging to him.

div.head: Minimi Digiti Abductor.
div.p: THe Fingers beides Flexion and Extenion,This abduceth the Little Finger. and being brought to the ides, are both adduced and abduced; then aid to be adduced when they are drawn towards the Thumb; abduced, when they are retracted from thence: and the Mucles which do perform thee Motions are many, ome of which are accounted common, others proper; the common are commonly reckoned eight, the which from their ite are generally called Interoei.

This Mucle called Minimum Digitum Abducens, is planted in the bottom of the Hand under the Little Finger, hort and trong, ariing Flehy from the fourth Bone of the Carpus, and o extending it elf by the Metacarpe, is inerted into the outward ide of the firt Joynt of the Little Finger.

This Mucle doth abduce the Little Finger from the ret of the Fingers, e. and hath given it this particular Ue, that whilt we do apprehend Sphaerical Figures, the ame time, the Little Finger is abduced from the ret.
This is call'd alo Hypothenar by ome Authors.
This you have hewn you at Tab. 19. at Q. Fig. 1. At Tab. 20. you have at P. in this place, At Tab. 21. Fig. 1. you have it in itu, And at Fig. 2. of the ame Table it is laid bare at E. E.

div.head: Pollicis Abductor.
div.p: THe Thumb when moved laterally,This abduceth it from the Little Finger. is either abduced from the ret of the Fingers, or adduced; this Abducens arieth Nervous near the Flexor Primi Internodii Pollicis, from the Interiour part of the Bone utaining the Thumb; and then becoming Flehy, implants it elf by a Membranous Tendon into the firt Joynt of the Thumb, and this abduceth it from the Little Finger.

This is call'd alo Thenar according to the Greek Idiom which names the more protuberant parts of the Palm < in non-Latin alphabet >
à
precutiendo.
e.
This you have at Tab. 19. Fig. 2. at Q. & Fig. 1. at R. O. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 2. Tab. 22. Ae. Shews the ame in place, Tab. 21. Fig. 1.

div.head: Pollicis Adductor.
div.p: ADducens is that which is een in the pace between the Pollex and the Index, This brings the Thumb to the Little Finger. and arieth Flehy from the outward and back part of that Os Metacarpi that utains the Fore Finger, and is inerted Flehy and broad to the inide of the Thumb to the firt Joynt, and doth adduce the Thumb to the Index.
This is call'd Antithenar by ome Authors. e.
This you have at Tab. 21. Fig. 2. at H. And at O. Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. At Tab. 20. you have it at Fig. 2. at H.

div.head: Interoei.
div.p: THee Interoei are generally accounted eight,Thee work the Fingers laterally. Flehy and mall, and long, ariing from the Bones of the Metacarp, according to whoe whole length they do march; when thee do attain to the Roots of the Fingers, they become Tendons, and are laterally inerted from the firt to the econd Joynts; there are ix of thee planted in the three Joynts of the Bones of the Metacarp, (viz.) two in every one, o as one is carried to the inward, the other to the outward Finger, and another thereof belongs to the firt Bone of the Metacarp which utains the Index, and is incumbent in that part which repects the Thumb; the lat adheres to the lat Bone of the Metacarpus in the outward part of the Hand, or in its back thereof.

Thee Mucles by how much they do attain the ret, e. do alo extend the econd and third Bone, which is firt oberved by Galen 1 de uu part. 18. and this is the reaon, why the Extenor of the Fingers being cut, yet their extenion is not quite abolihed: for thee Interoei working together, do very excellently perform this Extenion, and as they are implanted to the firt Bone, if either of one of the Fingers be contracted, they do extend the firt Joynt, if either, it either doth abduce or adduce it.
This you have at f. G. H. H. H. at Tab. 2. Fig. 2. At Tab. 2. you have the ame at N. N. N. N. Fig. 1.

div.head: Extenor Carpi exterior, ive Radiaeus Extcrnus, eu Bicornis.
div.p: THis is accounted the firt of the outward Mucles of the Carpus, This extends the Carpus. it arieth from the External accuminated part of the Arm, with a broad and Nervous beginning, then growing more Flehy, he runs by the Radius according to its length, and arriving half way, it marcheth into a trong Tendon, and is preently inerted with a double Tendon into the firt and econd Bone of the Metacarpus; and hence by reaon of its double Inertion and Origination, is by ome called Geminus.

The Ue of this Mucle is to extend the Carpus.
e.

This you have at Tab. 22. Fig. 1. at E. B. B. Shews the ame, id. Tab. Fig. 2. a. Shews its beginning, b. d. Its Tendinous Termination, I. K. K. Shews the ame laid bare, Tab. 23. Fig. 2. I. Shews its beginning, K. K. Its two Venters, b. b. Declares its two Tendons produced thence, L. M. Shews them alo at Tab. 20. Fig. 2.

div.head: The Explanation of the One and twentieth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: D. Part of the Tendon of the third Flexor of the Thumb.
f. f. f. f. Shews their Originations.
g. g. g. g. Their Tendons.
G. G. G. G. The four Tendons of the Flexores Tertii Internodii.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: C. C. Primus Secundi Pollicis Internodii Flexor laid bare.
D. D. Secundus & Tertius Secundi Pollicis Flexores.
E. E. Duo minimi digiti Abductores.
F. G. G. H. H. Interoei.
b. b. b. The Tendons thereof.

div.head: Extenor Carpi Interior, ive Cubitaeus Internus.
div.p: THis arieth from the Internal Apophyis of the Arm,This de • h extend the Hand. as alo from the top of the Cubite, and being dilated through the Cubite according to his length near the Carpus, is turned into a trong and round Tendon, by which he is inerted into a Sinus, above the lower Appendix of the Cubite, and into the upper part of the Os Metacarpi of the Little Fingers.

That worthy Obervation of thee parts is,Ob. that all the Flexors are planted in the forepart, and do arie from the inward protuberance of the Arm, and that the Extenors are eated in the back part, and do take their Origination from the outward Extuberance: And thus the Hand by the benefit of the Carpus, joyned with the Radius, is made either to bend or extend it elf.

This you have at C. C. Tab. 22. Fig. 2. e. Shewing its beginning, f. f. Its Tendinous end, L. M. Shews both the Extenors alo at Tab. 20. Fig. 2. H. The ame laid bare at Tab. 23. Fig. 2. e. Shewing its beginning, f. Shewing towards its Tendon.

div.head: Digitorum Secundi & Tertii Internodii Tenor Communis.
div.p: AS there were ome Mucles which did inflect the Fingers,Thee do extend the econd and third Joynts of the Fingers. and others deigned for contracting the Thumb, o alo are there divere Mucles appointed for extention of the ame; This is nominated as the firt of the Extenders of the Fingers, it arieth partly Flehy, and partly Nervous from the outward Apophyis of the Arm, and becoming more Flehy, decending between the two Extenors of the Carpus, and then narrowing doth divide it elf into three round Tendons, which are included in a common thin Mucaginous Coat, and o are carried under the Annular Ligament, paing which, they divide themelves, and are inerted into the firt, middle, and third Fingers, at the econd and third Joynts.
Thee Tendons do reach to the ends of the third Bone, e. and do lodge under the Nails, whence follows, that uch harp and girding pains do happen in thee parts when any Injury falls upon them.
This you have at D. D. Tab. 22. Fig. 1.

div.head: Minimi Digiti Tenor.
div.p: THis arieth harp and Nervous from the ame part as the former,This doth ait in extenion. and for near half way is united to it, o as they eem all as one, but coming to the tranvere Ligament, it becomes a round, large, and Nervous Tendon, which is implanted into the firt, econd, and third Joynts of the Little Finger.
This you have decribed with the ret.

div.head: The Explanation of the Two and twentieth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: C. C. Digitorum Extenor Primus laid bare.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: H. Pollicis Extenor Primus laid bare.
I. Pollicis Extenor Secundus laid bare.

div.head: Supinator Radii Longus.
div.p: THis is called Longus, This brings the Radius outwards. becaue it obtaineth the longet belly of all the Mucles which do creep about the Cubite.

This arieth from the middle of the Os Humeri, and running obliquely over the Radius, at its bottom it becomes a Membranous Tendon, and is fatned to the upper part of the Appendix of the aid Radius, inclining omewhat inwards.
If this and its Companion be contracted towards their Originations they do move the Radius forwards as alo the Hand, e. the which is tied to the lower part of the Radius by the benefit of the Carpus.
This you have at Tab. 23. Fig. 1. at C. a. Shewing its beginning, b. Its Tendon, D. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 2. Tab. 23. a. Shews its beginning, b. b. Its Tendon.

div.head: Secundi & Tertii Pollicis Tenor.
div.p: THis arieth from the ame place of the Cubite as the former,This extends the econd and third Joynts of the Thumb. and acends obliquely over the Radius, and divides its elf into two unequal parts, yet cloely adhering, and is carried in a proper Channel at the Appendix of the Radius: the upper part remaining omewhat Flehy, yet at lat becomes a round Tendon, and is inerted into the Os Carpi which receives the Thumb; the other being preently ubdivided into two mall pieces of Fleh do at length become Tendons: the firt of which is inerted into the firt Joynt of the Thumb, the other by a Membrane, fixeth its elf to the econd and third Joynts of the Thumb.
This you have at Tab. 22. at H. & I. Fig. 1. 1. At Fig. 2. ejud. Tabul. hews the ame.

div.head: Indicem Abducens.
div.p: THis arieth with a Flehy Origination from the middle of the Cubite,This moves the <> laterally. and o running obliquely to the Appendix of the Radius, it becomes two Tendons, which by a proper Sinus in the aid Appendix are tranmitted under the Annulary Ligament over the Metacarp, and the upper Tendon is carried to the Root of the Little Finger, the other is implanted into the Root of the econd Finger obliquely, that it may abduce from the Thumb: it is accompanied with two Extenors of the Fingers in the lower Joynts, as the • cond and third.
This you have at F. Fig. 1. Tab. 22.

div.head: Supinator Radii Brevis.
div.p: THis being horter and thinner than Supinator Radii Longus, Th • helps <> in <> Motion. arieth from the Exteriour part of the Ligament of the lower Head of Os Humeri, and from the proces of the Cubite; and running obliquely (outwardly Membranous, inwardly Flehy) doth recover the middle of the Radius, and is trongly implanted into it.
Thee two Mucles if they do work together, e. they do contract the Radius forwards and outwards, and o do bring the Hand upwards: but the one draws the part downwards, and the other draws it upwards.

This you have at O. Tab. 22. Fig. 1. D. Shews the ame at Tab. ejud. Fig. 2. D. Shews the ame at Tab. 23. Fig. 2. c. Shewing its Inertion into the Radius, E. Shews it at Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. c. Shewing its Origination, D. Its Tendon.

div.head: Primi Internodii Extenores.
div.p: THey arie Flehy,Thee do extend the firt Joynts of the Fingers. round, long, and lender from the Bones of the Metacarp, and o running to the Roots of the Fingers, are laterally inerted to the firt and econd Joynts of the Fingers, and are to be raied as the Flexores primi Internodii; When thee Mucles are contracted to their Originations, the econd and third Joynts of the Fingers, together with the help of the Interoei are primarily extended, e. and in time of need, may erve to ait in oblique Motions: and wie Nature placed thee inwardly, that if by any michance the outward Tendons might receive any michief, or happen to be wounded, yet by the aitance of thee, the Fingers might be extended.
This you have at D. D. Tab. 20. Fig. 2. a. Shews its beginning, b. b. b. Its diviion into three Flehy parts.

div.head: The Explanation of the Three and twentieth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: D Supinator Radii Longus laid bare.
H. Shews the Ligament which ditinguihes the External Mucles from the Internal.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: D. Supinator Radii Brevis, c. Shews its Inertion.
H. Carpum Extendens Interior laid bare.
e. Shews its beginning, f. Its Tendon.
I. K. K. Carpum Extendens Exterior laid bare.
b. b. Shews its two Tendons.

div.head: Next come we to the Body it elf as it lies.
Serratus Major Poticus.
div.p: TO the former Mucles of the Thorax are alo added thee two,Thee do dilate the Thorax. o called Serrati potici from their Actions, as alo from their Indentings: and Potici being contrary to thoe Serrati we have already decribed, and they are alo called either Superiores or Inferiores from their places which they do poes.

This Mucle being mall is inerted in the Back under Rhomboides, between either Scapula, and upon the firt pair of the Mucles of the Head, ariing very thin and Membranous; from the Spinal procees of the three lat Vertebres of the Neck, and the firt of the Thorax, and in its oblique progres towards the Convex part of the Thorax it becomes Flehy, and is inerted into the four upper Ribs, by o many ditinct Terminations, and by drawing them upwards doth dilate the Thorax.
This you have at Tab. 24. at C. in itu, d. d. Shewing its beginning, e. e. e. Its end coniting of three orts of Fibres, D. The ame laid bare.

div.head: Serratus Poticus Inferior.
div.p:
THis Mucle is broad,This dilates the lower part of the Thorax. thin, and Membranous, placed almot in the middle of the Back under Latiimus, and the Anicalptor of the Arm, ariing from the Spines of the lower Vertebres of the Back, and the firt of the Loyns, and marching along tranverly becomes Flehy, and is inerted into the four lower Ribs by o many ditinct Terminations, the which drawing outwards doth dilate the lower part of the Thorax.
e.
E. Shews this at Tab. 24. f. f. Shews its Origination, g. g. g. Its Serrated Inertion, F. This Mucle laid bare.

div.head: Splenius ive Triangularis.
