div.p: THis arieth double:This brings the Head backwards. Firt, from the Spines of the fourth, fifth, third, econd, and firt Vertebres of the Thorax: Secondly, from the Spines of the five lower Vertebres of the Neck, and o running broad and long about the third Vertebre of the Neck, both the Originations do unite: and by oblique Fibres both Mucles do inert themelves into the middle of the Occiput; You mut take off from its Originations, and preerve as many of its Anulae as you can between the Spines by running between, and recovering its Tendon; If both move, e. they draw the Head directly backwards, if only one move, it turns the Head laterally.
This you have at Tab. 24. at A. A. A. A. Shews the ame at Tab. 26. This you have at B. B. alo Tab. 25. Fig. 1.

div.head: Trigeminus ive Complexus.
div.p: THis is the econd pair of the Extenders,This extends the Neck. lying under the former, and is called Trigeminus, becaue it has allowed it a threefold Origination, and eemeth to be conflated out of three Mucles running into one: it hath various beginnings, and obtains both many and Nervous parts; it arieth threefold, firt, from the fourth and fifth tranvere Procees of the Vertebres of the Thorax and immediately becoming Flehy doth acend over the ret of thoe Vertebres, until he reacheth the lowet Vertebre of the Neck, where it becomes a round Tendon; Not far from thence again it becomes Flehy, and inerts it elf into the middle of the Occiput; The econd Origination is by a hort round Nerve from the ame Proces of the lat Vertebre of the Neck, and thence becoming Flehy is joyned to the other before its Inertion; The third Origination is partly Flehy, and Nervous from the tranvere Procees of the firt and econd Vertebres of the Thorax, and running obliquely outwards, after union with the former, is inerted into the Root of the Mammillary Proces, betowing an Anula upon every tranvere Proces of the Neck. To find this fairly, divide the ides of Spinatus, and Longiimus Dori, and his Origination will more plainly appear.
Riolanus doth oberve that the Fibres both of this Complexus and Splenius to be interected and dipoed cros-ways for the better trengthning of either Mucle.Ob.
B. B. Shews this at Tab. 24. B. B. Shews the ame at Tab. 26. C. Shews the ame laid bare at the ame Table.

div.head: Tranveralis.
div.p: THis arieth from the tranvere Procees of the ix upper Vertebres of the Thorax, This extends the Neck. and o growing thicker, is implanted externally into all the tranvere Procees of the Neck, and hence had it given it its name, and doth draw the Neck backwards: but one of thee only working, e. they bend it obliquely downwards; between thee are carried the Nerves of the Spinal Marrow, paing out of the Vertebres of the Neck.
This you have at E. E. Fig. 2. Tab. 25.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twenty fourth Table.

list.item: A A. Triangulare by ome called Splenius.
b. b. Shews its firt and econd ides.
e. e. e. Shews its Termination.
D. Shews the ame laid bare.
F. Shews the ame Mucle laid bare.
h. h. Shews its Flehy beginning.
L. M. N. The ame laid bare.

div.head: Spinati Colli.
div.p: THis pair are long and large,This extends as the former. poeing the whole Neck, between the Spines: it arieth with many beginnings from the Roots of the Spines of the even uppermot Vertebres of the Thorax, and acending, gets a Tendon out of every tranvere proces of the Vertebres of the Neck, and is firmly implanted into the whole lower part of the econd Spine of thee Vertebres, and there the right and left do meet, and are o all the way united, that they are not diviible but by the Spine; e. Thee with the former do alo extend the Neck, and then the Head, either directly, if they work together, or if they work ingly or apart, it brings it obliquely.
F. f. f. Thee you hall have at Fig. 2. Tab. 25.

div.head: Recti Majores.
div.p: THee are the fourth pair:Thee extends the Head. this Mucle is mall, thin, and Flehy, ariing from the points of the Spines of the econd Vertebre of the Neck, and acending, are inferred into the middle of the Occiput, and doth help the motion of the third pair.
Thee are generally held to be the fourth pair of the Neck, and are granted to give aitance to the former in their Extentions.
This you have at E. Fig. 1. Tab. 26. At 25. you have them at C. C. At b. b. you have them, id. Tab. Fig. 2.

div.head: Recti Minores.
div.p: THee pair lying under the former,Thee do help the former. being of the ame ubtance and hape, accompanied with the like ductus, do arie from a mall protuberance of the firt Vertebre of the Neck round, and acending, are implanted as the former underneath them; by the benefit of thee Majores and Minores, if the whole pair work together, it extends the Head directly, e. but if one only move, it is moved laterally.

Nature hath made o many Mucles for extention of the Head,Ob. that Man might more aptly fit himelf for the Contemplation of Coeletial Bodies, and for this Motion, mall Mucles were thought mot requiite: and let they might tire or grow weary in their long dependence, Providence hath ordered to thee, long Mucles, more properly adapted for a longer bowing of the Head, or extending it to a harper Angle.
Thee you have at Fig. 1. Tab. 25. at D. D. Fig. 2. ejud: Tab. you have them at b. b.

div.head: Obliqui Superiores.
div.p: THe ixth pair are planted under the Recti or the forementioned,Thee do turn the Head about. anwering their form or hape, being but mall, and ariing from the outward ide of the Recti at their implantations, and obliquely decending, are inerted into the proces of the firt Vertebre of the Neck: if both move, e. they nod, and directly backwards: if only one, it inclines the Head laterally.

Thee are called Obliqui from their ite, and one pair are implanted above another, either of which do lie under the Recti Extendentes, whoe ubtance and form they exactly do anwer. Bauhinus will have thee to arie in the Occiput, and to end in the lateral procees of the firt Vertebre of the Neck.
Thee you have at F. Fig. 1. Tab. 26. At Tab. 25. you have the ame at E. E. Fig. 1. Fig. 2. ejud. Tabul. you have them at e. e.

div.head: Obliqui Inferiores.
div.p: THis lower pair arieth longih,This helps the former. Flehy, and thin from the Spine of the econd Vertebre of the Neck, and obliquely acending, are inerted with the Obliqui Superiores into the tranvere Proces of the firt Vertebre.

When thee are contracted, e. they work it about the Spine circularly, whence it is, that the Head coniting upon the ame, it is alo moved circularly therewith to the ides; but becaue thee two pair are very mall, the two former pair of Extenors, they do help thoe in their Motion, as alo thoe of the right, as we have already hewn.
Thee you have at Tab. 25. Fig. 1. at F. And at d. d. you have them at Fig. 2. ejud. Tab.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twenty fifth Table.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: f. f. f. f. Spinati Colli.

div.head: Longisimus Dori.
div.p: THis Mucle hath not this name given it,This extents the Thorax. only becaue it is planted between the Mucles of the Back, but being as the longet of the whole Body: for it arieth from all the Spines of the Os Sacrum, and Vertebres of the Loins, as alo from the inward part of the Os Il • on, where it joyns it elf to the Sacrum, being the firt and chief pair, its beginning being externally trong and Nervous, and omewhat Acute, but within Flehy, and o acending, doth fix it elf to the tranvere Procees of the Loyns, and becomes more Flehy; then marching on, it narrows it elf, and gives a mall Nervous Tendon upon every tranvere Proces of the Thorax, except the twelfth, and doth inert it elf into the aid Proces of the firt Vertebre of the Thorax, although ometimes it attains the Mammillary Proces.

This is allowed to extend both the Thorax,
e. the Loyns, and their Vertebres: upon this borders the whole Sacrolumbus in its outide, whoe beginning with this is one and the ame, and is alo continued from the end of the Os Sacrum to the twelfth Vertebre of the Thorax, and o continued in its whole progres through the Loyns.
This you have at H. H. Fig. 1. Tab. 24. I. I. Shews the ame laid bare in the Right ide, H. H. I. You have the ame at Tab. 26. b. b. The ame laid bare.

div.head: Sacrolumbus.
div.p: THis Mucle lieth under Serratus Poticus Inferior, Th • helps the form • r in extending the Thorax. having the ame Origination with Longiimus Dori, and doth adhere to him externally lateral, according to its length, until it hath got the twelfth Vertebre of the Thorax, where they eem to be two, although carce diviible by diection, and o growing thinner, doth inert it elf by two mall Tendons into every Rib of the Thorax at their Incurvation.

About thee Tendons there doth arie a great dipute amongt Anatomits; e. for ome with Laurentius do think this Mucle to end forth a double Tendon, one upwards to the lower parts of the Ribs, the other downwards to their upper part; and thee Tendons thus diverly mediating (which are manifetly een about the Ribs) are een to attol the Ribs upwards in inpiration, and to draw them downwards in expiration; The truth is, thee contrary actions are not to be reaonably conjectured to be acted by one certain Mucle: and that it may very well be allowed, that thee decending Tendons ought to proceed from ome other peculiar Mucle, here upon a diligent enquiry, we find them to proceed from a certain Mucle ubtrated to the Sacrolumbus, and to this it is o cloely annexed, that it is carce perfectly to be eparated from it.
This you have at K. K. Tab. 24. L. M. N. The ame laid bare.

div.head: Cervicalis Decendens.
div.p: THis takes its Origination from the third,This doth extend the Thorax. fourth, fifth, ixth, and eventh Vertebres of the Neck, and hence by Diemerbroeck is Chritened by the name of Cervicalis Decendens, thence ariing Flehy, ending forth Tendons, omewhat downwards into the upper part of all the Ribs, directly oppoite to thoe Tendons of the Sacrolumbus, and thee Tendons thus interecting themelves, do not work together but by turns; As the Tendons of the Decendentis Cervicalis, do draw the Ribs upwards in • piration,Expiration. o the Sacrolumbal Tendons in expiration do draw the Ribs downwards, o as they may be moved to, and contracted by them.
As to this Mucle the Author will further atisfie you, and therefore I recommend you to Diemerbroeck.

div.head: Sacer.
div.p: FOr the various Motions of the Back and Loyns,This extends the Loyns. as forwards, backwards, and laterally, to every of the Vertebres are implanted Tendons of Mucles; Our Accurate Diectors of late have found four pair of Mucles to be planted in the Back and Loyns, by whoe help, the trong Motions of thee parts are performed: ome appointed for Contraction, others for Extenion.

This pair are o called from their Origination, becaue they do arie from the Exterior part of the Os Sacrum, where they are joyned to the Spine, and o ariing Flehy, have three everal Tendinous Inertions: the firt into the upper part of the tranvere Procees of the Vertebres of the Loyns, the other into the Root of the ame Procees, and the third into the Spine of the ame Vertebre; To find this out, you mut raie Latiimus Dori, and Sacrolumbus from their Membranous Originations; at Os Ileon, Os Sacrum, and from the Lumbal Spines, and immediately under this will this appear in itu, thee helping forwards the action of Longiimus Dori.
This you have at L. M. N. at Tab. 26. L. M. Shewing its beginning, N. Its Termination.

div.head: Semipinatus.
div.p: THis is the fourth pair,This extends the Thorax. ariing with a Nervous beginning from all the Spines of the Os Sacrum, and Loyns, and becoming Flehy, doth betow a Nervous Tendon upon every Spine of the Vertebres acending, and terminates acutely in the Spine of the firt Vertebre of the Thorax, extending it.

This by Spigelius is accounted the econd pair of the Mucles extending the Thorax.
e.
This is hewn at Tab. 26. at K. K. c. c. Shewing its beginning, d. Its Termination.

div.head: Quadratus.
div.p: THis Mucle is called Quadratus from the reemblance it hath with a quare:This Mucle extends the Loyns. it arieth from the back part, and upper Cavity of Os Ileon, as alo from the upper part of Os Sacrum, broad, thick, and Flehy, and o acending over the Vertebres of the Loyns, doth adhere internally to their tranvere Procees, and inerts it elf being grown narrower, to the inner part of the twelfth Rib Flehy, and doth bend the Vertebres of the Loyns forwards: e. and one only working, it bends it obliquely forwards to the ides.

The Loyns are concerned with three Motions, e. the which are performed by two pair of Mucles, for they are bent forwards, extended backwards, and brought laterally, they are contracted by thee two, and extended by Sacer.
This you have hewn at R. R. Tab. 26.

div.head: Poas vel Lumbaris.
div.p: SInce Ambulation is the proper office and work of the Foot, and this being very conitent in Firmation and Motion, (for when one Foot remains on the Ground, the other is lifted up, and o inoved forward for the compleating of Ambulation) now for the performance of either of thee Functions, its very requiite thee parts hould be furnihed with uch Mucles as may make forwards towards thee Extenions and Contractions, as alo to the promoting of the various Motions of the Thigh, Leg, and Foot, thee being according to our pleaures either extended, contracted, adduced, abduced, and wrought or brought about: amongt the Contractors we meet with this, as the firt called Lumbaris or < in non-Latin alphabet > .

It arieth Livid and Flehy from the ides of the Bodies of the two lat Vertebres of the Thorax, This bends the Thigh. and the three uppermot of the Loyns, and from their tranvere Procees decending omewhat round from the inner part of the Os Ileon; to the Os Pubis, where it becomes a trong and round Tendon, and running through its Sinues, e. is implanted into the upper part of the leer Rotator: Its Ue is to draw the Thigh upwards, and to bend it inwards; and becaue the Kidneys do lie upon this Mucle, as Laurentius doth oberve,Ob. over which is pread a notable Nerve, hence it happens, that uch as are troubled with the Stone, do find a leepines in that ide of the Thigh whereon the Stone is lodged, by its compreion.
D. D. Shews this at Tab. 27. b. b. Shews its Origination, E. Its Tendon, F. F. The Nerves which pas hence into the Thigh, G. G. G. The ame laid bare.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twenty ixth Table.

list.item: a. a. a. Shews its Anulae.
H. H. I. Dori Longiimus laid bare.
b. b. Shews the ame wholly laid bare.
a. a. a. Shews its inward Face and Anulae.

div.head: Poas Parvus.
div.p: BEides the former, in ome Bodies is een this Poas Parvus, This doth help the former. o called by Bauhine, it arieth Flehy the length of a little Finger, and is dilated with a lender and plain Tendon above the Poas, and ends with the Poas and Ileon, and embraceth them very firmly; Riolan. affirms he never could find this in Women; Bartholine writes, that he aw this Mucle ariing in a trong and Flehy Man at the Hague, Ob. whoe beginning was Flehy, and did equal the breadth of three tranvere Fingers; it was inerted Flehy in the upper Poterior Margent of the Os Ilii, Its e. at the Origination of the Iliacus Internus: he uppoed its Ue to be as a Pillow to the former, and that whereas the Os Ileon of it elf was immovable, or that it might utain the Os Ileon erected, let by the tanding too much thereon, it might caue a wearines and prove burthenom.
Our Mater of Anatomy, Mr. William Molins in the Year of his being Mater doth mention this Mucle, in the Body then Diected by him.
This Mucle lies under the former, but appears not very frequently.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twenty eventh Table.

list.item: G. G. G. The ame laid omewhat bare.
L. L. M. M. M. The ame laid bare.

div.head: We arrive now to the taking the Thigh off from the Trunck of the Body, by dividing Os Ileon from the Os Sacrum, after which, will this appear as the mot proper Order of Diecting thee following Mucles.
Iliacus Internus.
div.p: THis is the econd Mucle of the Thigh,This contracts the Thigh directly. proceeding from the whole Spine of the Os Ileon emicircular broad, and internally Flehy, then narrowing, and growing thicker becomes Tendinous, and paing through the ame Sinus with the Poas, is implanted into the ame Rotator a little below it. This is allowed to bend the Thigh directly, that is, when it is raied towards the Body, e. o as that it inclines to no one ide, and when we make a right Angle with the Spine, then we properly ay the Thigh is contracted, when itting we it with contracted Thighs.
This you have at 27. Tab. at I. I. I. L. L. The ame laid bare id. Tab. M. M. M. Shews its Flehy beginning.

div.head: Glutaeus Major.
div.p: THis is the firt of the Extenders,This extends the Thigh obliquely backwards. the which with its other two doth make up the Flehy Mas of the Buttocks, the Skin being laid bare, this hews its broad beginning, enated from divere Bones: it arieth from the whole Spine of the Os Ileon externally, then from the lower part of the Os Sacrum laterally; And thirdly, from the Os Coxendix large, and Flehy, running obliquely down over the Juncture of the Os Coxendix; and growing narrower is implanted by a broad and trong Tendon into the firt Impreion of the great Rotator, and part of it alo the Linea apera.
Then we properly do affirm the Thigh to be extended, e. when it's brought outwards, (viz.) as when we tand as it were with divaricate Thighs, or Thighs that are placed at a ditance.

This you have at Tab. 28. at C. C. C. a. a. a. Shews its upper part, b. b. Its other part, H. I. K. The ame laid bare. H. H. H. The thick and Flehy beginning of it, 1. 1. 1. Its thick Belly, K. K. Its Tendinous Subtance.

div.head: Glutaeus Medius.
div.p:
THis Mucle arieth under the former,This extends it obliquely forwards. much like it both in ite and magnitude, from the forepart of the Spine, as alo from the back of Os Ileon, Flehy, broad, and emicircular, and obliquely decending, narrows it elf, and doth enwrap the Juncture as the former, and is implanted by a broad, trong and Membranous Tendon tranverly into the fourth impreion of the great Rotator;
e. This is aid to extend the Thigh and draw it upwards, and laterally forwards, as ome imagine, but I humbly conceive it aiteth the Glutaeus Major, and depreeth the Os Femoris: and after it is lifted up by the Poas and Iliacus Internus, this Mucle pulleth it down again, and is as an Auxiliary Mucle to the Glutaeus Major, and Minor, in the extenion of the Thigh.

L. L. Shews this Mucle in itu at Tab. 28. e. e. Shews its Flehy beginning, B. B. Shews the ame in itu, Tab. 29. D. e. f. Shews it laid bare, D. D. D. Shews its Flehy beginning, E. Its Flehy Belly, F. Its Tendon.

div.head: Glutaeus Minor.
div.p:
THis lies wholly under the econd,
<…>
ariing livid, broad, Semicircular and Flehy, about the lower part of the back of the Ileon near the Acetabulum of the Coxendix, and o runs obliquely forwards Fibrous, according to the Ligament that binds in the head of the Os Femoris, and is implanted by a broad and trong Tendon into the third impreion of the great Rotator.

Thee three do extend the Thigh, and do draw it backwards, and o extend it. e. I conceive it mot probable, they all unite in pulling the Os Femeris downward and backward, after it is elevated by the Flexors, the Poas, and Iliacus Internus.
This is hewn at Tab. 29. at G. G. a. a. Shews its beginning, This you have laid bare at Tab. 29. at a. a. a. b. b.

div.head: Iliacus Externus vel Pyriformis.
div.p: THis Circumagent Motion is performed when the Thigh is Circumverted;This brings the Thigh about upwards. which thus happens: when tanding with the Right Foot firm upon the Ground, we move the Thigh obliquely; this Motion is twofold, for its either brought outwards or inwards: outwards when the Knee is moved outwards, and the Heel inwards: inwards when the Knee is brought to the Ham, and the Heel forwards; Amongt thee Circumagent Mucles this is reckoned the firt

It arieth thick and Flehy from the three lower Vertebres of the Os Sacrum, and running tranverly becomes a round Tendon, and is inerted into the fourth impreion of the great Rotator, This draws the Thigh upwards, e. outwards, and backwards, this is allowed the thicket Mucle in Human Body, and is tuffed out with wonderful variety of Fibres.

This is hewn at Tab. 28. at M. f. Shews its beginning, g. Its Tendon, H. Tab. 29. Shews the ame in itu, K. Shews the ame laid bare, L. Shews its beginning, M. Its long and lender Tendon, This you have laid bare at Tab. 32. at L.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twenty eighth Table.

list.item: a. a. a. Shews the Circumference of its Origination.
H. I. K. The ame laid bare.
H. H. H. Shews its firt and Flehy Origination.
C. C. Shews its Flehy beginning.

div.head: Obturator Internus ive Marupialis.
div.p: THis arieth Flehy and large from the Membrane internally that covers the great perforation of the Os Pubis, This brings the Thigh round about outwards. and covering the whole inward face of that Bone and Coxendix, grows narrower, and ends forth three or four Tendons which are carried through the Sinus of the Coxendix, which is arched over, according to its length, with a trong Ligament, backwards to the outwards part of the Coxendix, where they are received into a Flehy Pure, and o making one Tendon, are implanted into the Sinus of the great Rotator, and doth make the outward Rotation; This Mucle mut be raied inwards, and got through the Sinus under the Ligament, then its Pure will plainly appear.
This is hewn at Tab. 28. at Q. Q. O. Shews the ame at Tab. 2 • . This you have alo, Tab. 29. at D. E. F. G. G. Shews the ame laid bare, H. Shews its Flehy Pure.

div.head: Quadrigeminus.
div.p:
THis arieth Flehy from the riing of the Os Ileon, This brings the Thigh about backwards. and from the Appendix of the Coxendix, and runs broad, hort and Flehy towards the hinder part of the great Rotator, and is inerted into that pace of the Bone which is between the two Rotators; the head of
• ividus and part of Triceps mut be thrown off, before the Origination of this will be cleared, or Obturator Externus found out.
This Mucle by Vealius is divided into two M • cles.

Thee Circumagent Mucles do then bring the Thigh about,Ob. when tanding directly, and firm on the Earth we move the Thigh obliquely, and this Motion appears double, as outwards or inwards; that properly granted inwards, when the Knee is brought toward the Poples, and the Heel carried outwards: that outwards, when the Knee is carried outwards, and the Heel brought inwards.
This you have at Tab. 30. at I.

div.head: Obturator Externus.
div.p:
THis hath its name from its Origination,This brings the Thigh about inwards. it ariing from the outward part of the Cavity, and is ubjacent to the Pectinaeus, it ariing large and Flehy from the Membrane that enwrappeth the perforation of the Os Pubis externally, and o running tranverly to the back part of the Thigh, becomes narrower, and is inerted by a trong Tendon into the the Sinus of the great Rotator,
e. and doth direct the inward Rotation. You mut carefully bring your Knife inwardly about the edge of the perforation of the Os Pubis, and it will both arie and appear the better.
This (together with the Internus) fill up the Cavity which lies betwixt the Os Pubis and Ichium, whence it has its denomination.
This you have at Tab. 32. at H. I. K. Shews the ame laid bare, C. C. Shews the ame at Tab. 30 S. Shews the ame at Tab. 31. This you have alo at Tab. 32. at H. in its place, I. K. Shews it laid bare.

div.head: The Explanation of the Twenty ninth Table.

list.item: D. D. Shews its broad and Semicircular head
F. F. The Marupium or Pure it elf.
G. G. Shews the ame laid bare
a. a. a. b. b. Glutaeus Minimus laid bare.
m. m. m. Shews Triceps in itu.

div.head: Membranous.
div.p: THe Leg hath three motions allowed it,This extends the Leg directly. it being either extended, contracted, or brought omewhat obliquely outwards, all the Extenders are implanted in the fore ide of the Thigh, and thee working together, do extend it aright; This Mucle by Anatomits is reckoned as the firt of the Extenders.

It arieth harp, externally Nervous, inwardly Flehy, from the Spine of the Os Ileon, on that ide next Sartorius, and then becomes broad, and Nervouly Membranous, enwrapping all the Mucles of the Thigh within its elf; then covering the Patella and two Focills in their outward part, is there implanted, and doth extend the Leg directly; e. and as ome Authors will have, doth omewhat abduce it outwards.
As much as poibly may be, is to be kept of this Membrane in Diection, and the diviion thereof to be made in the back part.
This yon have at Tab. 30. at M. M. O. O. O. M. M. Shewing its beginning, O. O. Declaring its broad Tendon, Q R. S. Shews the ame laid bare.

div.head: Sartorius ive Facialis.
div.p: THis Mucle hath its name from its daily ue which is made of it by Taylors,This bends the Leg. and Shoomakers, who when they be at their work, do generally it Cros-leg'd, ome call this Facialis from Facia, a Ligature or Swadling Band.

It arieth harp, Flehy and Nervous from the fore part of the Spine of the Os Ileon, and then becoming Flehy and broad, runneth obliquely internally over the Mucles of the Thigh, becoming Tendinous and broad at the inward Appendix of the Os Femoris; and is implanted by a broad Tendon, as ome Authors affirm, and round, as others into the Tibia.

Riolan.
e. writes, that this doth not bend the Leg, but rather doth bring it inwards, and o he uppoeth doth more aptly extend it; This is one of the longet Mucles in Human Body.
This you have at Tab. 30. at A. A. B. Shews its Origination, C. Its Termination, D. D. Shews the ame laid bare, T. Shews it alo at Tab. 27.

div.head: Gracilis.
div.p: THis is generally accounted the econd of the Contractors:This doth ait the former. it arieth large and Nervous from the middle of the Os Pubis, according to the length of its Cartilage, and o decending inwards towards the Ham Flehy, doth there become a round Tendon, at the inner head of the Os Femoris, inerting it elf into the Tibia near the former.

The firt and econd of the Flexors are planted in the fore part of the Thigh,Ob. the one outwards, the other inwards, the ret in the back part thereof; if they be all contracted together, they do bend the Leg directly, but the firt four only working, they do bring it omewhat inwards, whilt the other endeavours to carry it outwards, and by this motion, the end of the Foot in which the Toes are implanted is omewhat brought outwards.

This is hewn at F. F. in its place, Tab. 30. G. Shews its Commiure, H. Shews its Inertion, I. K. L. Shews the ame laid bare, I. Shewing its Nervous beginning, K. Its round Belly, and L. Its round Tendon.

div.head: The Explanation of the Thirtieth Table.

list.item: D. D. Shews the ame laid bare.
I. K. L. The ame laid bare.
Q. R. S. The ame Mucle laid bare.
V. V. Triceps in either ide.
b. b. Vatus Internus in itu.

div.head: Vatus Externus.
div.p: THis from its great Mas of Fleh,This alo doth extend the Leg. hath its name given it, and is the third of the Extenders, ariing broad and Nervous from the Root of the great Rotator, cleaving to the upper and outward part of the Os Femoris, and o decending Flehy to the Patella, it becomes a Membranous broad Tendon, and mixing with the Tendon of the Rectus makes the ame covering for the Patella, carrying the ame inertion with it.
This you have at G. G. G. G. in its place at Tab. 31. H. Shews the beginning of this Mucle, I. Its Tendinous Membrane.

div.head: Vatus Internus.
div.p: THis is the fourth extending Mucle,This works as the former. ariing Nervous from part of the leer Rotator, and from the neck of the Os Femoris, and growing Flehy, adheres to the Anterior, and Interior part of the aid Os Femoris, and recovering the Patella, mixeth it elf with the two former, covering the Patella, and taketh its inertion in the ame place as they do.
This you have at L. L. L. Tab. 31. This you have alo in its place at Tab. 30. at v. v.

div.head: Biceps.
div.p: THis is the fifth inflecting Mucle,This doth contract the Leg. ariing harp and Nervous from the Appendix of the Coxendix, and growing Flehy, runs down externally, and being got half way, it attenuates and grows Nervous, as tending to a Tendon, where it joyns it elf with its other head which arieth from the Os Femoris, where Glutaeus Major hath its inertion, and o growing thicker, outwardly Nervous, becomes a trong Tendon, and runs through the outward Sinus of the outward part of the head of the Os Femoris, and fixeth it elf firmly to the outward ide of the upper Appendix of the Fibula; Sometimes this Mucle is ditinguihed with a double beginning and ending,Ob. o oberved by Vealius, and therefore by him this is called Duplex.
This Mucle doth bend the Leg and pull it backward. e.
This you have laid bare at Tab. 32. at O. O. At Tab. 29. you have it at M. V. Shews this laid bare at Tab. 29. X. Shews its beginning, Y. Shews its Tendinous Subtance, Z. Its Flehy Mole or Subtance.

div.head: Semimembranous.
div.p:
THis is accounted the fourth of the Inflectors,This bends the Leg. ariing where the former did, with a mall Membranous beginning, and running downwards by the back part of the Thigh, doth continue Membranous half its progres; and then becoming Flehy and thick, inerteth it elf by a round Tendon into the Ham, in the inner ide of the
• ibia; The firt of the four Inflectors being tied into the inner ide of the Tibia, and the fifth into the Fibula; the firt makes the inward hardnes in the Ham, the other, the outward.
This you have at Tab. 29. at L. You have the ame laid bare at R. S. Shews its Nervous Head, T. Its broad Tendon.

div.head: The Explanation of the One and thirtieth Table.

list.item: D. E. F. The ame laid bare.
D. Shewing its harp and Nervous Origination.
G. G. G. G. Vatus Externus.
Q. Q. Q. Q. Triceps in either ide.

div.head: Seminervous.
div.p: THis hath its name from its Subtance,This works as the former. it being partly Nervous, and partly Flehy, and is the third pair: it arieth mall and Nervous from the ame Appendix as the former, and o continuing half way in its decent, it then becomes Flehy, running by the back part of Os Femoris, to the Ham, near which it becomes a round Tendon, and reflecting it elf, is inerted into the forepart of the Tibia.

This Tendon hath allowed it this worth obervation,Ob. that it reacheth even to the middle of the length of the Tibia, with the ret of the Tendons implanted to the Tibia, the which do care decend o far.
This you have at Tab. 29. at K. O. Shews the ame laid bare, P. P. Shews its Nervous beginning, Q. Its Nervous Tendon.

div.head: Triceps.
div.p: THis is the larget of all the Mucles of the Thigh,This brings the Thigh inwards. yea, I may ay, of the whole Body; its apparently een to have three heads, all which do conclude in one end: It a • ieth with three heads, the firt Flehy and Nervous from the Appendix of the Coxendix, the which welling, doth dilate it elf into the hinder part of the Thigh, and then growing mall, doth end in a round Tendon, at the inner head of the aid Os Femoris; The econd arieth Flehy from the Coxendix at its conjunction with the Pubis, and terminates at the Root of the leer Rotator, and in the upper part of the Apera Linea; The third arieth Flehy from the lower part of the Os Coxendix, and is implanted into the Linea Apera of the aid Os Femoris; To which ome add a fourth, (viz. the following call'd Pectineus) which eems to be a part of this.

This is a Riding Mucle, e. drawing the Thigh inward, and fixeth the Rider to his Seat, keeping him firm in the Saddle, and may be truely tiled Muculus Pudicitiae, as aited by the Lividus in keeping the Legs cloe.
This you have at Tab. 31. at Q. Q. Q. Q. A. A. A. A. Shews it in Tab. 32. B. Shews its beginning, D. D. D. Shews the ame laid bare, E. Shews its beginning, F. G. The diviion of its Tendon.

div.head: Lividus ive Pectinalis.
div.p: THis is allowed the fourth of the Inflectors,This bends the Thigh obliquely inward. it arieth broad and Flehy from the forepart of the Os Pubis, near its Cartilage, obliquely decending, and is inerted by a large and hort Tendon to the inide of the Os Femoris, near its middle, o as it trongly brings the Thigh upwards and inwards.
By Bartholine this Mucle is reckoned amongt the Adducent Mucles.

This Mucle is aitent to the Triceps,
e. being an Adductor of the Thigh, which it pulleth inward, being very ueful in Riding, keepeth a Horeman cloe to the Saddle; and (as was before aid) eems to be a part of the Triceps, though it does not o cloely adhere to it, but it may be eparated without difficulty.
This you have at Tab. 29. at A. A. A. A. B. Shews the forepart of the Os Pubis, from whence this Mucle takes its Origination, O. Shews the ame at Tab. 27.

div.head: The Explanation of the Two and thirtieth Table.

list.item: D. D. D. The ame Mucle laid bare.

div.head: Gaterocnemius ive Gemellus Externus.
div.p: THe Foot hath allowed its threefold motion, (viz.)This ex • ends the Foot. Extenion, Contraction, and lateral Motion; this is accounted the firt of the Extenders, which maketh the Calf of the Leg: it arieth broad and Flehy from the inner head of Os Femoris, as alo from the outward head of the ame Bones; o decending according to their Originations, they are united about midway, and are converted into one entire, broad, trong, and Nervous Tendon, and becometh one with the Tendon of Gaterocnemius Internus, and doth inert it elf into the back part of Os Calcis, o that indeed they are but one Mucle with a double Origination.
Vealius doth aert that the Seamoidal Bones are Tributary to the two heads of this Mucle, not far from their Origination.

This you have at Tab. 33. at D. E. F. G. H. Fig. 1. D. Shews its firt Origination, E. Another of its beginnings, F. Its Coherence, G. G. Shews its large Flehy Belly, H. Shews its large Tendon, at Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. O. P. Q. S. Shews the ame laid bare.

div.head: Plantaris.
div.p: AS that Mucle Is called Palmaris, This moves the Skin of the Sole of the Foot. which with its long and round Tendon doth march through the whole Interior part of the Cubite, and from thence to the Annular Ligament of the Carpus, and is afterwards-expanded into a broad Tendon covering the whole Palm of the Hand; o alo is this Plantaris expanded through the whole hinder part of the Tibia, with a long and round Tendon, and at length marcheth into the Sole of the Foot.

It arieth Flehy, round, and lender under the former, from the outward lower head of Os Femoris, and after ome Dilatation, it becomes a lender round Tendon, and running obliquely from the outward between both the Gaterocnemii inwards, and being joyned with their Tendons near the Heel laterally, running forwards, doth inert it elf (after Dilatation over the Sole of the Foot) into each of the five Toes at the firt Joynt.

The Dilatation of this Mucle over the Sole of the Foot,Note. as alo its Inertions, will not be found, unles you allow it to inert it elf into Flexor Primi Internodii at its Origination in the Cavity of the Os Calcis.
This Mucle is of as great ervice to the Foot as Palmaris is to the Hand; e. and erves to the Extention, or Expanive Motion of the Foot.
This you have at Tab. 3. Fig. 2. at I. K. K. I. Shewing its head, K. K. K. Its round Tendon.

div.head: Gaterocnemius Internus, eu Soleus.
div.p: THis arieth livid,This extends the Ancle. trong, and Nervous from the Poteriour Appendix of the Fibula, and growing larger, adheres both to that and Tibia, and decending at half way, it becomes narrower and Tendinous, making one with the Gaterocnemius Externus both in Origination and Inertion; Thee three Mucles are united about their ends, and do frame one very trong Tendon, implanted in the back part of the Heel, the which by reaon of its greatnes, and ingular trength above the Tendons of other Mucles, obtains the name of Chorda Magna, the which being Bruied or Wounded, (as Hipp. writes) proves Mortal or very dangerous: its by this Tendon at this very day that our Butchers do daily hang up their Oxen by;Ob. And that which is worthy obervation as touching this, is, that if any Inflammation doth arie about this part, it brings the whole Body mierably into conent therewith.
This you have at L. M. N. Fig. 2. Tab. 33. L. Shewing its trong and Nervous head, M. Its large venter, N. Declaring its Tendon.

div.head: Suppopliteus.
div.p: THis arieth broad and Nervous from the outward head of Os Femoris, This moves the Leg obliquely. and growing Flehy, runs obliquely to the back and inward part of the upper Appendix of the Tibia, and is there implanted.

p.U: aith, e. he ometimes hath found this double; This moves the Leg obliquely outwards, and turns the Foot omewhat inward towards the other.

div.p: This you have at G. H. Tab. 33. Fig. 3. G Shewing its beginning, H. Its Termination.

div.head: Flexor Digitorum Tertii Internodii, eu Perforans, ive Sublimis.
div.p: THis arieth Flehy,This bends the Toes in the third Joynts. and long from the back part of the Tibia, running, and adhering according to its length, to the middle of it, and there becoming a Tendon, is carried to the Internal Matleolus, where it becomes round, and is carried under the Ligament that proceeds from the lower Appendix of the Tibia, to the Os Calcis, and then divides it elf into four Tendons, which terminates at the third Joynt of the four leer Toes.

The Toes of the Feet are both contracted,Ob. extended, and moved laterally; And for thee three Motions, Nature hath deigned three kind of Mucles, and thee are called either Flexors, Extenors, or Oblique Movers; four of thee are implanted in the Leg; as this firt, the Flexor of the Great Toe, and the Extenor of the third Joynt of the Toe, and the Extenor Pollicis; the other in the Foot.

L. L. L. L. Shews the four Tendons of this Mucle at Tab. 37. Fig. 2. B. Shews the Tendon of this Mucle, Tab. 37. Fig. 2. D. D. D. Shews its Fleby part, E. E. E. E. Shews its four Tendons, F. F. F. F. Shews thee alo and their Originations at Tab. 37. Fig. 2. H. Shews this alo at Tab. 34. Fig. 1. I. Shews its middle part, K. Its Exquite Tendon, D. D. E. Shews the ame, Fig. 2. id. Tab.

div.head: The Explanation of the Three and thirtieth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: D E. F. G. H. I. Gaterocnemius Externus.
E. A econd of its Originations.
G. G. Its large Flehy Belly.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: O. P. Q. Shews Gaterocnemius Externus laid bare.

div.head: Tibiaeus Poticus eu Nauticus.
div.p: IT arieth Flehy from the Ligament which joyns the Tibia and Fibula, This brings the Foot inwards. according to their length, and from both Bones backwards, becomes a round Tendon, near the Malleolus Internus, where being bound by a trong Ligament, it overpreads it, and recovering the Sole of the Foot, is inerted into that lower part of that Os Tari, which joyns it elf with Os Cubiforme; Sometimes there is een, that it hath produced two Tendons, the one implanted into the Os Naviculare, the other into the Innominated Bone.

This Mucle is called Nauticus from the ue which Seamen make of it,
• . when they do run up the Shrouds.
This you have at Tab. 35. Fig. 1. at E. E. e. Shewing its Flehy beginning, f. Declaring its Tendon, D. D. D. Shews the ame at Tab. 36. Fig. 2. E. Shewing its Tendon.

div.head: Flexor Pollicis.
div.p: THe Great Toe hath allowed it variety of Mucles,This bends the Great Toe. the firt of which is this ariing harp and Flehy about the middle of the back part of the Fibula, decending larger, nearer the inward Malleolus, running obliquely under it, and is inerted into the lat Bone of the Great Toe; Under this Ligament lodgeth the Os Seamoides.

This Tendon is een ometimes to conjoyn with the Tendon bending the third Joynt,Ob. running to the econd Toe, and before it reacheth the econd Joynt of the Great Toe, requires the larget Os Seamoides, which is in the other Joynts of the Toes.

This you have at Tab. 37. Fig. 2. c. Shewing its Tendon, D. D. D. Shews its Flehy part, Tab. 36. Fig. 1. at N. you have it laid bare, M. Shews this at Tab. 34. Fig. 1. N. Shews its long and narrow Tendon, I. I. Shews the ame exactly at Tab ejud. Fig. 2. K. K. Shews its Tendon, N. Shews this laid bare at Tab. 36. Fig. 2.

div.head: Flexor Secundi Internodii, Perforatus eu Profundus.
div.p: THis is a econd of the Inflectors of the Toes,This bends the Toes in the econd Joynt. by ome called Flexor Brevis, it arieth Flehy and Membranous from the extremity of Os Calcis, and marching half way the Sole of the Foot, divides it elf into four round Tendons, which at their Inertions into the econd Joynts of the leer Toes are perforated for the tranmiion of the Tertii Internodii Flexor.

This you have at Tab. 37. Fig. 1. at C. C. C. D. D. D. Shewing its four Tendons; And at Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. you have the ame laid bare at N. O. Shewing its Origination, P. P. P. P. Declaring its Tendons, Q. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 34. Fig. 2. N. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 37. Fig. 2. O. Shews its Origination, P. P. P. P. Shews the four Tendons of this Mucle.

div.head: The Explanation of the Thirty fourth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: P. P. Gaterocnemius Internus laid bare.
R. R. R. Shews its long and round Tendon.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: D. E. E. Flexor Tertii Internodii Digitorum.
E. E. E. Its lender and Flehy Venter.
L. L. Peroneus Primus in itu.

div.head: Flexores Primi Internodii Digitorum, eu Lumbricales.
div.p: THee are called Lumbricales both from their Ue,Thee be • ds the firt Joynts of the leer T • es. Figure and Origination, much reembling Earth-Worms being put into the Hand.

They do arie round and and Flehy from the Tendons of the Perforans and Perforatus, and are inerted by mall Tendons laterally to the firt Joynts of the Toes; if you examine this well, you will find them to receive an addition of Carnous Fibres from a Muculous Fleh eated or implanted in the inward Cavity of the Os Calcis, and proceeding Flehy half the Sole, there doth make thee; and from it ometimes doth proceed a Tendon to the firt of the Toes, and makes Secundi Internodii; and you hall alo find that the Tendon of the Tertii Internodii Flexor doth run through the Body of this, and is not perfectly diviible.

Thee you have at Tab. 37. Fig. 1. at K. K. K. K. F. F. F. F. Shews the ame at Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. R. R. R. Shews their Flehy Mas laid bare at Tab. 36. • ig. 1. S. S. S. S. Shews the Tendons whence they do arie, T. T. T. T. Shews their four Tendon • .

div.head: Adductor Pollicis Major.
div.p: THis arieth Nervous from the inward part of the Heel,This brings the T • es tow • rds. and from the Ligament, which keeps that and the Talus together, and o growing Flehy and round, becomes Tendinous, inerting it elf obliquely into the lateral and inward part of the firt Joynt of the Great Toe.
This abduceth the Great Toe from the ret of the Toes;Ob. or, as I may ay, draws it inwards.

This you have at Tab. 37. Fig. 1. at E. F. F. Shewing its Tendon; At Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. you have the ame laid bare at Q. Q. M. Alo hews the ame at Fig. 1. Tab. 35. laid bare, O. Shews this at Tab. 34. Fig. 1. R. Shews the ame laid bare, Fig. 2. ejud. Tab.

div.head: Abductor Minimi Digiti.
div.p: THe Little Toe hath a particular Abductor allowed it,This abduceth the little Toe from the ret. from the Heel, ariing Nervous from its External part, and growing Flehy in its progres, runs with a mall Flehy Tendon under the Os Metari, which is immediately plac'd before the Leat Toe, and o is inerted into the External ide of its firt Joynt.

This you have at Tab. 37. Fig. 1. at G. G. H. H. Shews its Tendon, I. I. Shews the ame l • id bare at Fig. 2. ejud. Tab. L. M. Shewing its Tendon, K. K. Shews its beginning, Q.
• hews the ame at Tab. 35. Fig. 1. P. Shews this at Tab. 34. Fig. 2.

div.head: Adductor Minor, ive Tranveralis Placentini.
div.p: THis by Caerius, This draws the great Toe to the little Toe. who firt found this out, gave it the name of Tranveralis, becaue it binds the firt Joynt proceeding from the Ligament of the Little Toe, and is carried tranverly Flehy, and marcheth out with a hort and broad Tendon inwardly, to the firt Bone of the Great Toe.

The Author of this Mucle doth aign this Ue to it, e. That drawing the Great Toe towards the Little one, it makes a hollownes in the Foot; o as that in unequal and tony places, an apprehenion as it were being hereby made, we may tread and walk more teadily, and commodiouly, this being as a Ligament to the Foot, to keep it from lipping or liding, and for a more ecure ambulation; for by the help of this Mucle, the Foot is brought into that Figure, that it makes the tep ure, and as it were doth apprehend the part it is et on.
This you have at Tab. 37. Fig. 4. at E. laid bare, H. Shews the ame at the Letter A. the firt Toe, P. Shewing the ame at Tab. 36. Fig. 2. P. Shews the ame at Tab. 35. Fig. 1.

div.head: Tib • eus Anticus, ive Muculus Catenae.
div.p: THis is the firt of the Inflectors,This bends the Ancle. whoe Tendon being tranverly diected or amputated, the Patient is compelled to carry his Foot in a Sling, by the benefit of which he is able in his paage both to lift up and inflect his Foot.

This Mucle arieth harp and Flehy from the uppermot Appendix of both the Focils, forwards: as alo from the Ligament which binds them together, then being dilated, is narrowed about the middle of the Tibia, growing into a trong and round Tendon, running obliquely over the Tibia, and under the Annular Ligament, and is implanted into the inide of that Os Tari that is therefore Os Pollicis.
This Mucle I conceive governeth the Foot in motion, e. that it doth not quail to m • ch outward.
This you have at Tab. 35. Fig. 2. at C. C. a. Shewing its beginning, b. Its Termination and Tendon, M. N. Shews this at Tab. 36. Fig. 1. O. Shews its Tendon.

div.head: The Explanation of the Five and thirtieth Table.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: I. I. Extenor Tertii Internodii Digitorum
M. M. M. Shews its Tendon.

div.head: Fibulaeus ive Peronaeus Primus; aut Poticus.
div.p: IT arieth Nervous from the upper Appendix of the Fibula, This brings the Foot outwards. and decending, it adheres to the outward part thereof, being externally round, inwardly livid, next the Mucle red, and marching half way, it becomes a Tendon running obliquely backward through the Sinus under the external Malleolus, and is inerted into the Root of the Os Tari, that adjoyns to the Os Pollicis.
This Mucle draweth the Foot omewhat outward, e. and o regulateth it in Progreive Motion, that it cannot be cat too much inward.

This you have at Tab. 36. Fig. 1. at B. C. D. D. Shewing its Flehy Belly, D. Its Tendon, V. Shews the ame laid bare at Fig. 2. ejud Tab. L. L. Shews that at Tab. 34. Fig. 1. L. L. Shews the ame at Tab. ejud. Fig. 2.

div.head: Peronaeus Secundus ive, Semifibulaeus, aut Anticus.
div.p: THis Mucle arieth long and Flehy from the Fibula, This bends the Ancle. to which it adheres, and having made half its progres, becomes a round Tendon, running by the External Malleolus, and is implanted by two Tendons into Os Metatari, adjoyning to Minimus Digitorum.
This Mucle is alo called Semifibulaeus, it being a near neighbour to the Fibula; As alo by Spigelius is named Bicornis from its double Inertion into the mall Bone adjoyning to Minimus Digitorum.

This you have at Tab. 36. Fig. 1. at E. E. F. Shewing its Tendon, I. I. I. Shews the ame at Fig. 2 ejud. Tab. K. Shewing its Tendon, G. G. Shews the ame laid bare at Tab. 35. Fig. 1. H. Shews its Tendon and place of its Inertion, H. H. Shews the ame at Tab. 35. Fig. 2.

div.head: Pollicis Tenor.
div.p:
THis arieth Flehy from the Fibula (or as Vealius offereth) from the outward ide of the Tibia, This extends the great Toe. where it parts from the Fibula, as alo from the Ligament that joyns them, to which it trongly adheres, and o becoming a Tendon, runneth over the lower part of the
• ibula, and under the tranvere Ligament, and is inerted into the two Joynts, in the upper part of the Great Toe, e. and doth extend them directly; ometimes this Tendon is een divided into two: one of which is inerted into the lat Joynt of the Great Toe, the other into the Os Metatari which lies jut under it.
This you have at L. Tab. 36. Fig. 1. b. Shewing its Tendon, N. N. Shews this laid bare at Fig. 2. Tab. 35. O. Shews its Termination.

div.head: The Explanation of the Six and thirtieth Table.

list.head: FIG. I.
list.item: H. H. H. H. Shews its four Tendon.

list.head: FIG. II.
list.item: R. R. T. T. Lumbricales laid bare.
R. R. R. The Flehy Mas from whence they do arie.
S S. S. S Shews the four Tendons whence they do arie.
T. T. T. T. Shews their own four Tendons.

div.head: Extenor Tertii Internodii Digitorum, aut Longus.
div.p: THis arieth with a Nervous and Flehy beginning,This extend • the third Joynts of the Toes. from the outward, and forward Appendix of the Tibia and preently becoming Flehy, and adhering to the Ligament that joyns the Tibia and Fibula, it decends directly according to the length of the Fibula, and paing under the Annular Ligament, e. it is divided into four Tendons, the which do terminate in the upper part of the third or lat Joynt of the four leer Toes, and o extends them.
The other Tendons are tied amongt or between themelves by a certain Membranous Ligament, where they run through or over the back of the Foot.
This you have at G. Tab. 36. Fig. 1. H. H. H. H. Shews its four Tendons, I. I. Shews this at Tab. 35. at Fig. 2. K. Shews its four Tendons.

div.head: Extenor Secundi Internodii Digitorum, aut Brevis.
div.p: THis arieth broad and Flehy from the tranvere Ligament upon the top of the Foot,This extends the econd Joynt. and then appears, dividing it elf into four everal Mucles, which coming to the Toes, endeth forth Tendons to the econd Bone of the four leer Toes, but chiefly to the econd Joynts, where they interect the Tendons of the former. e.
Thee two are allowed to extend the four leer Toes.
This you have at Tab. 35. Fig. 2. at L. M. M. M. Shews its Tendons, S. Shews the ame at Tab. 36. Fig. 1.

div.head: Interoei.
div.p: THee have their names from their habitations,Thee move the Foot obliquely. they dwelling amongt the Bones; Thee Mucles do arie Flehy from the ides of the Bones of the Metatarus, and are inerted by ome broad, but hort Tendons, into the firt Joynts of the Toes outwardly, but inwards to the econd Joynts thereof. The outward working, they do abduce the Toes: e. the inward do adduce them; they both working together, do extend them.

In the Sole of the Foot, which by ome is called Vetigium, is a Flehy Mas obervable, the which like a Pillow or Bowlter doth keep warm the Tendons of the Mucles of the Foot, the which ome Anatomits, although confuedly, do joyn with the Muculus Tranveralis.
Thee Mucles you have delineated at Tab. 37. Fig. 3. at C C. C. C. C. D. D. D. D. D. And at F. F. F. F. F. G. G. G. G. G. in the Toes by themelves.

Thus have I concluded the whole Dicoure of Mucles; all I hall farther add, is, the Enumeration of them, with their Reductions to their proper Places, Ues, and Offices, being either Relative to the Venters or to the Articulations, having already preented and drawn forth to you every of their Forms and Shapes: as alo hewn their Originations and Terminations; leaving you Directions, how to find out every Mucle in its order by a proper Index made for that purpoe.

div.head: This Table heweth the Reduction of the Mucles each to their proper place.
